description:
To paraphrase Guy Fieri on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives, so much pastrami, call my mommy! 

A lunch here is so damn big you'll take leftovers back to your office and eat a second meal that day. Or, if you're me, save a giant matzo ball soup for emergencies. When my co-workers and I rolled up to the museum-side takeout window, there were several orders in front of us. In fact, one person ahead of us ordered a whole small office's worth of sandwiches, hence the hold up.

Several of us ordered the $17-ish. sandwich-and-soup combo: for me, that consisted of pastrami on double-baked rye, and that massive matzo ball soup cup. The pastrami I ate fresh, and wow -- it's melt-in-your-mouth good. In a strange way, it was very similar to a thick-cut bacon, but made with beef and much less salty. I really enjoyed that the 'bark' of the pastrami wasn't so peppery, and that the double-baked rye crust was so crunchy. It also came with a small cup of creamy potato salad, which was on the sweet side.

The matzo ball soup I enjoyed an hour later, determined to try it even though I was full. The ball is super filling and flavorful, a nice contrast to what matzah typically tastes like, and pairs very well with the egg noodles and white meat in the broth. Wise Sons drops in just a hint of dill, which does wonders for deepening the broth's flavor. Reheated, it's just as good.
author: Gwen W.

description:
Always come here for the classic reueben. Because why not, hellos. The only reason I'm giving four stars is because it's too expensive to order at a window and even having to pick up your order their too. 

The sandwich does taste amazing, the pickle on the side adds a little extra mmmpphhh, and the side salad is a good finishing touch, but it's very small~~ a mere few bites. 

I'd recommend giving it a shot if you don't mind dropping $20 on a sandwich. I'd come back when I felt like splurging on myself.
author: Alexander H.

description:
Wise Sons cancelled my catering order 2 hours before it was supposed to be delivered. I have a huge business meeting at noon and I had to scramble and cancel my meetings so I could find a place that would make a last minute order for 20 people. 

I ordered 30 hours before I needed it on Caviar, when they only require 24 hour notice. Someone named Ryan told the Caviar rep "We are too busy, so just cancel their order." What!?!?!

Amazing food, I really do love the food. But I can't believe how unprofessional they acted in this case.
author: Elizabeth A.

description:
This is a good place to eat fancy Jewish sandwiches. I got the pastrami sandwich with potato salad, blt sandwich with coleslaw, stumptown iced cold brew, and Arnold Palmer. Everything was very high quality and delicious! It is pricier than your typical sandwich because everything is made in house and so fresh.

On nice days, you can eat outside. And on not so nice days you can eat inside the museum. The museum was designed by Daniel Libeskind, a famous starchitect, so it was very nice! The high ceilings, brick, and blacked steel looked very grand and luxurious.
author: Andrea T.

description:
I love Matzo ball soup and this place has bits of chicken and noodle in the Matzo ball soup.

It's a great comfort food to me downtown, and located near the Jewish Museum, it's convenient.

Their soup and sandwich (pastrami or your choice) for $14 is a better deal if you're hungry.

I think it's a good option for tourists and locals who want a good meal, but aren't really feeling the food trucks near by.
author: Jack R.

description:
Decent spot for a pastrami sandwich. Perhaps a tad small for the $14 price but it'll hold you for a little. The pastrami was well-seconded and moist. The rye bread held its own with all the juices. Pickle provides a nice counterpoint and your choice of potato salad or coleslaw complete the meal.

Not the most seating but great if you can score a table outside - especially if it's sunny. Note it can be quite a wind tunnel though so hold on to those paper plates. Come because you crave a Jewish deli sandwich; otherwise you can can get more for your money even at full-service spots close by.
author: Jon L.

description:
We always love going to Wise Sons in the Mission and were happy to get the chance to eat at the downtown location after a morning at the SF Moma.

There's outdoor seating (you order at a window from a limited take home menu). You can also go inside (through the quick museum security first) and eat your food inside or out.

The Contemporary Jewish Museum is beautiful, with plenty of lighting, extremely high ceilings, and geometric lines. 

* Reuben w/ Pastrami ($15.50) - 4.5 stars
A go-to fave for my boyfriend. He gets this every time!

* Club Sandwich ($14) - 4 stars
A simple, fresh sandwich. I don't usually like cole slaw, but this was light and I enjoyed it.
author: Ziyan C.

description: This place is fun to go to at the Jewish museum. I had the matzoh ball soup again and it was a nice snack. I should try a sandwich. It's a nice atmosphere.
author: Denise C.

description:
Dude. What an amazing Reuben! 

I'm a total sucker for the Reuben sandwich as it's a goto order whenever I see it on a menu. I'd been to Wise Sons on Fillmore and experienced a mediocre bagel/lox sandwich so was hesitant to come back to a different location but, boy I'm eating my words now. 

As mentioned before, I ordered the Reuben and opted to combo the meats (pastrami/corned beef). The sandwich comes on rye bread with sauerkraut, cheese and russian dressing. I always opt for deli mustard instead of the russian dressing and they were happy to accommodate. The result was a beautiful sandwich with QUALITY meat. Very surprised at how delicious it was. The side of pickles is a nice touch too...

I'll def be back.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Cool space but sadly this place is not worth it. Weirdly enough, good Jewish delis in SF are practically non existent. Was hopeful to try their No. 19 pastrami sandwich that is described as a tribute to Langer's Deli in Los Angeles.

Hate to break it to Wise Sons, but Norm Langer would be insulted with this skimpy salt bomb. Pastrami portion very meager and ultra salty, almost to the point of inedible. Rye is good but everything needs to work for a great pastrami.

I won't be coming back and will stick to the pastrami at Langer's. This is not even close!
author: D C.

description:
I passed by during my lunch hour and their takeout counter happened to be open.  I've been meaning to try this for a while, so stopped by and ordered their lunch combo (half a pastrami sandwich and a cup of matzo ball soup). 

This ended up being one of the pricier lunches I've had in San Francisco but was tasty. I'm not sure how to compare the quality of the food to Jewish food in general, but the sandwich was well put together and tasty. The matzo ball soup was...strange.

I liked the location - there's a number of tables outside the counter (which is accessed from the outside) - and I'd probably suggest as a future lunch meeting spot, for this reason.
author: Sunil S.

description:
Tldr - solid lunch place in a great location!

Great flavorful sandwiches, my turkey bad boy was a tangy delight to eat! The avocado paired amazingly with the turkey meat and onion. The mayo also made a creamy delight when it was combined with however the avocado was prepared. 

Restaurant is a bit tough to find, take a look at the photos. It's a literal hole in the wall attached to the Jewish contemporary museum. 

The block is on is a pleasure to eat in with a concrete fountain that is nice in sun. But also you can walk across the street to a bit articulate park and dine in some pretty views. When it's nice out the lemonade specifically hits the spot.

Coleslaw was just Aite nothing to write home about.

All in all this place was a perfect working lunch. However I don't think the sandwiches are so amazing that I would drive in and find parking to go here. If you're in the area and looking for some grub on a nice day, this is the best answer.
author: Samraaj B.

description: Solid Jewish food! Great spot if you're craving your favorite Jewish dishes but a little too expensive for a regular lunch spot. Loved their Reuben sandwich their potato salad, and their mustard!  Take your time reading the menu even if you have to step aside to let others through. Not a bad spot to hangout for a while if you've got some time. You can sit and inside if you go through a short security checkpoint or you can order from their window and sit outside.
author: Cole E.

description:
Delicious! Absolutely delicious! 

I stopped by for lunch to bring back to the office and surprisingly, not packed at all! I ended up getting the Rueben with combo meat (pastrami and corned beef). Also comes with a side of cole slaw or potato salad. I opted for the cole slaw. 

Got back to the office and took my first bite. One of the best Ruben sandwiches out there! I'm so glad I ordered mixed meat! Bread was still crispy and meat had so much flavor. It also comes with a side of pickles which was standard and cole slaw was mediocre. 

I must say it's pretty pricey for a sandwich.  $18 is steep but I really enjoyed the food and will be back!
author: Elaine C.

description:
The ONLY negative I have to say about this is that they have very limited hours (11-2), so plan accordingly.

On to the important stuff. The pastrami salmon is AMAZING! I almost wish I had gotten my bagel untoasted because it kind of makes a mess and looses a bit of its "chew" but the combination of warm bagel, cold cream cheese, crunchy cuke/onion and salty salmon is To. Die. For.  Do yourself a favor and get it asap.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Visited Wise Sons for lunch and was not disappointed.

The deli was good, but not stand out.. (Visit Katz's in NYC or Kenny & Ziggy's in Houston).

We started off strong sharing a combo of corned beef and pastrami with Cole slaw and Russian dressing. Sandwich was satisfying - soul food. 

Pro tip: get your bread toasted so it holds up to the cole slaw / Russian dressing. 

We then shared a half chopped liver sandwich and matzo ball soup.  The soup was classic with a giant ball. I would have liked it to be hotter but it was a classic reference of what matzo ball soup should be.

The chopped liver sandwich was tasty but lacking in chopped liver. :/ The slice of hard boiled egg was nice but I kept searching for more liver and all I got was bread and pickled onions. 

Egg cream was a bit of a disappointment in size and quality. The only bright spot was that they make them fresh from seltzer bottles. 

We finished with the chocolate babka and it was good.

A little more than $40 and we were stuffed.

If you're running by the Jewish museum, you could do worse!  Your belly will appreciate the soul food without a dose of judgement.
author: Dan K.

description:
Expensive but tasty Pastrami and Corned Beef sandwiches.

The chicken matzo ball soup is also very good and you can order a combo for half sandwich/soup if you want to try both. I'd recommend the classic corned beef sandwich. Each sandwich comes with a choice of potato salad or coleslaw, and a bunch of mustard packets (which taste great!). I prefer the potato salad, which is nice and creamy and goes well with the sandwich.

I also tried the lox bagel (smoked salmon). It was a bit too salty for my tastes, so I haven't had it again. But I'll keep coming back for the corned beef.
author: Joe B.

description:
Better than your average Jewish deli! This place is known for its corned beef and pastrami so absolutely try it if you're here. A New Yorker at heart, I cannot day CA bagels ever compare. I will say that the club sandwich was incredible as was the No. 19. The challah with the club sandwich is sweet and adds a nice crispyness to the sandwich. Oh, and their mustard is also delicious. 

A special place indeed.
author: Sela B.

description:
While I was at the San Francisco MOMA I yelped search for restaurants nearby and found this Jewish Deli. Its been a while since I had a real corned beef sandwich on rye bread! We took a break from the remarkable and outstanding art museum and went to find the Wise Sons Deli. 

It is located inside the "Contemporary Jewish Museum" a mere .2 miles away, except we walked all around the block looking for it (not realizing it was actually inside another building).  Be prepared for airport like security to get in.  It was a busy lunch time and there were no table seats available, but we found two at the counter.  At Wise Sons, you order at the register and they bring the food out to you.

We ordered the pastrami sandwich plate and the "downtowner" or something like that which is a half sandwich and a bowl of matzah ball soup. The sandwiches came on rye and were super tasty.  The best corned beef I have had in years.  The matzah ball soup had a gigantic matzah ball, the size of a baseball, and the soup was kind of bland, but honestly I am no aficionado of matzah ball soup so maybe it is supposed to be that way.  But put some salt and pepper on it!!!  We ate the sandwiches but left the soup. $41.
author: James S.

description:
Bottom line at the top: Tasty Food with High Price Tags

Yummy, expensive, quasi deli food, conveniently located at the Jewish Contemporary Museum. 
I splurged on the what I believe is their most expensive sandwich, the #19. They describe it as their tribute to Lander's Deli in L.A. with a choice of pastrami, corned beef, or smoked turkey with coleslaw, Russian dressing and cold Swiss ... $16. (choice of potato salad or coleslaw on the side.) For $16 I expected a deli sandwich, not a regular sandwich. 

- Regular sandwich is one you can fit into your mouth to take a bite and costs about $9.

- Deli sandwich is stuffed with so many layers of meat (or other filling) that you can't possibly take a bite, you either need to eat it with a knife and fork or take out half of the meat, which you save for later because you have enough left over to make second sandwich. $14 - $19. 

Lesson learned - I'll wait until I'm in New York or L.A. to get a deli sandwich but if you are in S.F. and just have to have one - this is the place to get something that tastes the same.
author: Evelyn S.

description: Love this deli! Fantastic breakfast and lunch options. My favorite rye bread, challah and rugelach in town! Nice to sit inside or outside.
author: Jenna L.

description: Yummmm! This was so good - excellent corned beef. Not too salty and delicious! Came with a side salad and the service was great.  Yummmmmm I highly recommend this! Wish they were all over the bay area
author: Ran M.

description: The corned beef Rueben was good but not the quality you would hope for inside a Jewish museum. The potato salad was undercooked and crunchy. I'm used to spending a little more at a Jewish deli but this felt overpriced for the quality. Great outdoor seating though overlooking the park.
author: Kacie L.

description: Overpriced. DO NOT buy the Matzo ball soup . It was the most bland thing that my husband and I have ever tasted. The coleslaw was just as bad as the soup.  If they gave me those items for free I would not eat either of them. Their potato salad was better. It taste better if you put a ton of mustard in it. I got the club sandwich, which was good, but needed more fried pastrami. My husband got a smoked white fish sandwich which was good as well. It would be nice to be able to save some money and not get the average and or unedable sides. The 2 sandwichs with 1 side for each sandwich and the horrible Motza ball soup cost over $40. Not worth it. Buy a jar of manischwitz matzo ball soup from the store it taste so much better and it is cheaper.
author: Kat M.

description:
- Taste: good
- Value: good
- Service: ok -- order at window
- Ambiance: good -- outdoor seating!

//The food
--- Kale Chicken Caesar (4.5 stars | $11)
LOVED the little sprinkled crunchy croutons, they reminded me of what smashed pita chips would be. Lots of chicken, great caesar dressing, served with rye.  HIGHLY recommend this, super yum.

--- Matzo Ball Soup (3 stars | $7.50)
Some shredded chicken and a giant matzo ball, not enough meet to justify $7.50 though. Felt very healthy though, comes with a good amount of carrots.

--- Babka (2 stars | $4)
Too dry for me, i just don't think I like Babka.. :( 

Friends enjoyed the reubens which come with pickles and potato salad. $15.50. 

//TLDR: Overall, would definitely come back especially on a sunny day!
author: Kristie C.

description:
On a recent trip to SF I had a strong hankering for mazah ball soup. Stopped by the walk up window and had a friendly conversation with the gentlemen working the window and inside.  They asked if I wanted the downtown special--potato salad, pickle, half pastrami sandwich, and soup! 

I went for it and while it was a significant amount of food, I did not leave behind a single bite. Hands down the best pastrami I have ever had and I fear I am ruined because I won't be able to eat it anywhere else now! Potato salad was delicious as was the matzah ball soup. That soup really hit the spot!! 

There is outdoor seating so I was able to enjoy my food while people watching. A good combination, I look forward to coming back in a few months when I'm in town again.
author: Melissa K.

description:
Much like the contemporary Jewish Museum that it sits in, Wise Son's Jewish Delicatessen seems a bit more of a new age perspective on classic Jewish Deli fare. 

A mushroom reuben? 
A kale Caesar? 
A smoked trout salad (their version of whitefish salad)? 

All things that you wouldn't dare find in the black and white tiled deli giants that call New York City home; but so is life right? Things are adapted, things are changed. Classics will always be classics, but the future deserves an ode too? 

Now, I read through some of the reviews before I stepped in and a lot of Yelpers were going back and forth on the price vs the thickness on the stacks of meat on their sandwiches. 

Now, I can tell you, I love a fist thick meat sandwich as much as the next Jew. I mean really. I am Jewish and I grew up with our father taking us to one or two particular restaurants in Rockville and Wheaton solely because of the thickness of their sandwiches. 

But, in this new day and age of health, we can probably both admit that no one really needs to eat one sandwich with three quarters of a pound of corned beef on it. Imagine how much meat would be in our deli drawers at home if that was a normal thing. 

Now, the deli near me in Bethesda does that, we all love it, but everyone ends up taking the second half of their sandwich home. Not a bad thing, I mean, you get 2 meals for the price of 1; but ya don't REALLY need a sandwich that thick. 

Now, I will admit that I was a little nonplussed to see the amount of pastrami on the club sandwich I got. 

When it hit the table, I literally thought they had accidentally made the club sandwich with bacon because I saw 1 singular piece of thin brownish reddish meat sticking out of the side. 

Then I was like... wait... I'm in a Jewish Deli... there shouldn't even BE bacon #SheDoesn'tEvenGoHere. What do we say to the G-d of Bacon in a Jewish Deli... Not Today. 

It WAS pastrami.

And then I went back to the menu... just to remind myself what I ordered, and it seems that they're making a play on a traditional club sandwich. 

They say "Smoked diestel turkey, crispy pastrami" etc.

Like the pastrami is suppose to be a substitute for bacon 

... clever... 

#ButHeresTheCatch... even on my Club Sandwich... I like more than one piece of bacon. Gimme gimme more.

The horseradish mayo is an absolute delight. Not too pungent, the mayo has a keen sweetness to it before it delivers a faint background of that unique horseradish spice. 

The potato salad that I got with my sandwich was probably one of my favorite parts of the meal. Not overladen with mayo, wonderful forward notes of dill. A real expert fine chop on the red onion and herbs. Really fresh and clean tasting. I'd love to get this recipe. 

And the last thing I ordered: The Pickle Plate. You can add a pickle plate onto any one of the sandwiches for an extra 4.50. 

It comes with: 

Pickeled carrots: Not a fan *strong taste of... tumeric?
Pickeled beets: Huge fan! Probably my favorite thing on the plate
Saurkraut: A solid fresh version that has a great toothsome bite 
Red Onion: Nah B *strong taste of... Anise... I'm sure of that one
Half Sour spears: I'm so so on this one. Not bad, but not great. 
Pickle rounds: Mustard seed? Something too strong is happening with this one as well.

If it was me, I'd let the vinegar sing a bit more than they tried to do with the spices. 

So... will I be back. Well, I'll tell you for 23.70 in San Francisco I was wonderfully stuffed. It was very quick, the service was good, and mustard gave me a compliment as soon as I sat down. 

No for reals... all the tables have a squirt bottle of spicy mustard that reads 
"Eat Something, You Look Skinny" on the back. 

I will be back. I still need to try the Matzo Ball soup, the corned beef, and the smoked trout salad. That was probably the hardest thing not to order, cause whitefish salad is MY JAM. 

Like... I don't think I've met anyone that enjoys whitefish salad as much as I do. Little secret: it'll actually be the name of my next I phone

Oh... and they serve all their sandwiches on enamelware! I know... it's a weird thing to love... but I'm me! You can be you ;)
author: Mike B.

description: Tried pastrami sandwich, matzo soup, potato salad and coleslaw. Pastrami, matzo soup and potato salad is pretty good, but not good enough for me to spend 15 more minutes to buy it at lunchtime. Can't stand the taste of coleslaw dressing.
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
I wasn't too crazy about ordering a pastrami sandwich cuz I'm more of a salami sandwich girl, but trust...that pastrami was perfect. At first, I was like, ok, I can do this. But as soon as it went into my mouth---I was like, Oh hell yeah, this is the shit! (in a good way--if you're not feelin my manner of speech). 

The pastrami had nice fat pieces of fat! The good kind! The rye was perfectly toasted and trust, they do not skimp out on the meat.  The sauerkraut was so perfect and the dude included 2 pickles in my order because I opted out of a potato salad. 

I'd definitely go here again but only when their lines aren't too long. Those who read my reviews know that I ain't patient for lines and crowds!
author: Sharon B.

description:
The food is great.  Best Pastrami in town.  Great side dishes.  Great soup!  Great counter help.  So what is the problem?
I could make a mortgage or buy lunch.  
Also when there is an event like MLK Day, get some more service in the kitchen and counter.  You can make more money and make more people happy.  
Think about a better value?  How can you make that happen?  
Good quality everything.  I know this is a challenge but you are Wise!  Love the food.
author: Elisa B.

description: Such a cute spot for a nice lunch or late breakfast. Whether you're craving some amazing pastrami or bagels. Or need some remedy for your cold- they got it. Must try. The pastrami sandwich is amazing and  even better with mushrooms added.
author: Jaklin G.

description: Unimaginably, it seems as though Wise Sons has gotten even better.  The pastrami even more tender and juicy.  Perfect amount of smoke. And the rye bread.  Without question the best I've ever tasted. I've been eating wise sons since they were popping up on Valencia, and I'm happy to see that they've continued to refine their craft... a rare thing when food folks expand their business.
author: ari b.

description:
Wait! Did you just trick me? Or, did I willingly pay $17.00 for some meat, bread and potatoes? Darn you San Francisco, why you gotta be like that? Truth be told folks, I did pay. Willingly. While I will always have a side eye for that sticker price, here me when I say, it was worth every cent! No line and no wait, my order was ready in under 10 minutes.

I've never been to New York, but when I think of the Jewish deli's you see in the movies, I envision a local corner shop where someone's granny is in the kitchen whipping up the family secret ingredients. Meats that are so tender they dissolve in one bite, potatoes so fluffy they could almost be whipped cream. Well, Wise Sons is that place. 

I figured going with the Reuben would be the most optimal item on the menu to get the full experience of what they're all about. I picked a winner! The meat is just the right saltiness. The Sauerkraut has the perfect blend of tanginess and texture, safe from vinegary and limp. No mushy sauerkraut here. I'm not even a fan of Rye bread but their organic fresh baked bread was so buttery and toasted precisely at the ideal level of soft and crisp that I even ate the crust!

Gooey, melted, thick cheese, russian dressing, and sauerkraut are layered on each slice of bread. Smacked in the middle is the meat. You have an option of Pastrami, Corned Beef or Smoked turkey - I went with the Pastrami option. 

Potato salad or Cole slaw accompany the sandwich as a side. When I asked for a recommendation, the young man at the window said the potato salad was really good. That potato salad was like my aunt's salad, thick, slightly chunky with a creamy blend. Mini bits of red and green onion and egg to seal the deal!

You guys! I gripe about the high cost of lunch in this city. Everyone does. Let's be frank though, I'd be a liar if I didn't tell you I wouldn't return to Wise Sons Jewish Deli. Maybe not on a regular weekly visit but they are definitely a new favorite.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
This place is nestled in the far right corner of the museum. Go through security and then hang a right.

Selection here isn't as large as their larger locations, but they make a perfect pastrami reuben! Bread is nice and toasted, pastrami super flavorful, moist and not dry. $15.50 and comes with a side. Never a super long line and quality is always great and consistent.
author: James S.

description:
Good jewish deli fare...you would hope so to be in the Jewish Museum in SF, but not amazing. The reuben is good, but could have used a little more pastrami, especially for $15. The rye bread was very good and nicely griddled. The matzoh ball soup was ok. It came out piping hot which was nice, but the matzoh ball was a little dense and i thought could have been lighter and better seasoned.

But it's a good place to get your jewish deli fix on.
author: David L.

description: A delicious Reuben sandwich. Lovely potato salad as too. So nice to have my favorite sandwich so close to work and done so well.
author: Clements J.

description: Really great sandwiches on amazing bread. Even the simple grilled cheese on challah was incredible. My 3 year old devoured it. Was just grabbing a snack while visiting the museum and wasn't expecting much but was blown away at how yummy everything was. The babka for dessert was light and delicious. Husband wished it was more rich/decadent but I thought it was perfect.
author: Aggie L.

description: I had the reuben with pastrami. I passed on the potato salad and opted for extra pickles instead. The pastrami reuben was one of the best Reubens I've ever had. The rye bread was fresh, the sauerkraut was flavorful, the pastrami was crispy and a bit salty and a balanced amount of Russian dressing all came together for a tasty sandwich.
author: David F.

description: Go for the Rueben w/ Pastrami. It's the best. Perfect balance of meat and other stuff.
author: Ash M.

description: This is at best a museum cafeteria - maybe the other locations would be better but the bagel and smear was very overpriced and at least day old. Disappointing.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
A Jewish deli at a Jewish museum. That's an excellent city planning maneuver. Or an obvious one.
It was a particularly warm day and many were enjoying their vitamin D intake on the grassy lawn out front. I intended to do the same with a little nosh, specifically babka. The take-out line at the kiosk wasn't long, but it was moving very slowly. I was getting impatient under the hot sun and schvitzing. 

$4 Chocolate Babka:
I've only had babka a couple of times in my life and I was curious to try it from the Wise Son's.  
I received a huge chunk that was about the size of one of their sandwiches (which are on the small side as sandwiches go). It was actually a little too big to eat gracefully, but I proceeded to dig into it anyway, like a predator unhinges its jaws to devour its prey.
The layers were flaky with swirls of chocolate and had some type of crumbly topping. It wasn't as fluffy or spongy as I had hoped though. 
I wrapped up the rest and took it home to enjoy.
Mr. Joy, who had never had babka before, had the genius idea to heat it up. It then became soft and the chocolate melted a bit. If you have the patience to pop your babka in the oven or a microwave, I'd suggest doing that. It was so much better.
Not that I claim to have any authority on what a proper babka ought to taste like.

Like any Jewish deli, they've got the usual pastrami & corned beef sandwiches, and bagels & smoked fish. & kale salad, of course. Because kale is everywhere. 
I have tried one of their reuben sandwiches, which was good, but was a small sandwich with a big price.
author: Joy W.

description:
I complained a little about the main Wise Sons, but was very pleasantly surprised with this iteration. I had the Number 19, which tries to emulate the same sandwich at Langer's in Los Angeles (and which is the finest pastrami sandwich on the planet). It's a good attempt, but lacks the flavor profile of the original (a little more like a kosher hot dog than true pastrami) and the freshly-rebaked bread of Langer's. That said, it's still a very good sandwich. 

The egg cream, though, is superb. While no egg cream is ever big enough, this one is a little smaller than I'd have liked, but makes up for the size with exactly the right flavor and accompaniment to the pastrami. That alone takes the restaurant up a star, from three to four.
author: Dave S.

description:
Tasty sandwiches and soups

Sandwiches are decent sized. Well balanced ingredients. 

Ordered the Reuben, potato salad, cole slaw, matzo ball soup

I found it a little pricey, but what isn't these days in downtown San Francisco 

It's a place to grab a quick lunch. 

You will have to bus your own table, but they will bring food to you. Order first then find a seat.
author: Lyman C.

description: Disappointing. Flavorless soup and heavy mazo ball. Weak chopped liver. Maybe some dishes are better.
author: Arom A.

description: This place blows gas!  As a member of the tribe, I'm used to a hearty sandwich. At $14+ for a pastrami sandwich, I expect a pretty good portion of meat. Alas, this place is skimpy and the sandwich sucks!  Wise Sons- please stop misrepresenting Jewish Delis.
author: Joycr I.

description: We came in on recommendation from a good friend and ended up loving the matzo ball soup and the pastrami classic. Service was fast and friendly, and the drinks tasted delicious. 10/10 would recommend for a quick meal, sit down lunch, or any occasion.
author: Allen A.

description:
You call yourself a Jewish Delicatessen and you don't have:
1) Egg Bagels
2) White Fish Salad
3) Chopped Herring
4) Sturgeon
5) Chub

The rugelach was overpriced.
The coffee was decent.

The best experience was the music and the server.
author: Michael C.

description:
Felt a little under the weather and wanted some chicken soup to comfort me.  Not wanting an Asian noodle soup, nor SF Soup Co.  I turned to Wise Sons.  There was a little bit of a line when I got to the take out window.  As other reviewers had mentioned there is a wait for food here.  I figured that my soup should've been easy since it's pre made and they just need to pour it into a container.  

The soup was a good size for about $8.  The broth wasn't very flavorful though, and there weren't much veggies.  The matzo ball itself was fine and there was a good amount of shredded chicken, but with bland broth, what's the point?  

Maybe their sandwiches and bagels are better but don't come here expecting delicious matzo ball soup or to get your order ready quickly.
author: Cat C.

description:
Lunch review. 

Bagels - 3/5 - 7x7
Pastrami sandwich - 3/5
Corned beef sandwich - 4/5
Chocolate babka - 2/5
Cinnamon babka - 4/5

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description:
I have no idea why I haven't been to this place considering all the years I've traveled to SF and stayed at the Park Central. But I guess better late than never!

My colleague and I were looking for a quick lunch that was easy on the stomach. Being raised by a Jewish mother told me we needed matzo ball soup. I was so happy to see that I could grab some so close to our hotel. 

We walked over and decided to grab to-go orders from the walk-up window. I got a bowl of matzo ball soup and a half corned beef sandwich. Yea, I know what you're thinking... I was supposed to be going there because I wanted something that was easy on the stomach. But, I can't say no to corned beef on rye bread. My pal ordered some soup and a bialy with lox and cream cheese. It was up in a jiffy and we were on our way back to the office. 

First, I really enjoyed the taste of the tender, thick cut corned beef. However, I can't help but agree that the serving size of meat is a little wimpy for the price. Sure, it was a half sammie, but corned beef sandwiches are known for being stacked. The matzo ball soup was delicious. Almost as good as my mom and I's. The matzo was tender, fluffy and just dense enough to hold together. The chicken stock was rich and loaded with chunks of white and dark meat chicken, carrots, and celery. It really hit the spot. 

I'll definitely be back for more delicious lunches.
author: Cara L.

description: I got the Asian chicken salad, $13.60 out the door. Very pricy for a simple salad, a couples pieces of orange and the chicken is dark meat and on the fatty side. I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Eva B.

description:
A classic pastrami sandwich is beautiful because of it simplicity. There are two, maybe three, components that work together harmoniously to create this tasty treat: Jewish rye bread, pastrami and perhaps a little bit of brown deli mustard.

Growing up with a grandfather who owned a market on Miami Beach and an uncle who owned a deli in Kendall, deli is something with which I am extremely familiar, and pastrami has long been my favorite. Smoky, peppery, tender, fatty warm and oh so delicious, pastrami is perfection and the Jews do it right! So when friends suggested we go to A "Jewish Deli" inside the Contemporary Jewish Museum, I was all over that like white on rice. 

The restaurant itself, being a museum restaurant, doesn't have much ambiance or atmosphere, but the ordering process and service is pretty well dialed in making for a nice place to dine. The menu is concise, with a definitive focus on their pastrami, offering everything from the classic pastrami sandwich to a vegetarian Ruben with smoked mushrooms. 

I settled on the classic sandwich with a side of coleslaw. Soft, slightly chewy, and studded with flavorful rye seeds, the bread they use here is the perfect vehicle to catch all of the juices dropping off the hot and delicious pastrami they pile high on this sandwich. A little spicy brown mustard and you've got the perfect pastrami sandwich everyone is after! The coleslaw was dressed lightly and creamy enough to cut through the pepper spice of the meat, yet heavy on the caraway or celery seed which added a wonderful herbal punch to it. Aside from the delicious taste, the "side" was mountainous.

All in all, this is a pretty good representation of what a pastrami sandwich should be, and Id gladly eat it again. I'm giving four stars for the location and the cinnamon babka, which was drier than the Sahara. Unfortunately I can't recommend something sweet to finish on.
author: Michael T.

description:
So glad we stopped in here! After I watched Deli Man and saw Wise Sons featured it was on my list of spots to check out while I was in San Francisco. This one is located within the museum so you do have to take a quick trip through the metal detector before going to order your lunch. We went at an off time so we were able to quickly order and get our food.

I went for the 1/2 sandwich and cup of matzo ball soup. The corn beef was on point. Since that is definitely not something you can find where I live in NC it was a welcomed treat. The matzo Ball soup was tasty but could have used more salt. I love that they filled it up with egg noodles, chicken, veggies, and dill. I hate when its pretty much just broth and matzo ball. 

The only disappointment was the babka, it was crazy dry and probably stale. That was a let down because it looked so delicious chilling out in the pastry case.
author: Holly K.

description:
Stopping at Wise Sons was a wise choice for lunch on-the-go during a recent business trip in San Francisco. If I had it my way I would have enjoyed the full experience--day at the Jewish Museum and a stop to the deli after. But, I had just enough time to grab a sammie from the walk up window and run to my hotel room to take advantage of a quick working lunch. 

I had a craving for corned beef and opted for a basic corned beef sandwich with potato salad on the side. Mind you, I live in the land of Jewish delis and have yet to meet my meat match. The corned beef here didn't hold up to my favorite stop at home. It was just okay and a bit on the dry side for me. They did supply numerous packets of mustard, which made it authentic, but I'm kind of bummed I didn't have the chance to check out the reviews prior to going. Without a doubt I would have ordered up the #19 like Jelena Z suggests. 

However...the potato salad goes down as some of the best I've had. If I had a potato salad list, this would be on it. It was creamy, chunky, and packed full of seasonings. I picked at it for a couple of days. Night snack for the win. 

Yep, the price was around $15, and even though I liked and not loved it, Wise Sons will be a stop the next time for sure. Hopefully one of these days I'll actually have time to visit the Museum.
author: Angela S.

description: Hands-down best Jewish deli in the city. Yes, it is worth the money. The other reviews here are embarrassing ‍
author: Aaron P.

description: Best deli in the city. My kids love the challah grilled cheeses for my older son could eat their Reuben every day. The Chinese chicken salad is delicious! They even have gluten free bagels.
author: Brooke R.

description:
I got the Downtown Special- matzo ball soup + choice of 1/2 sandwich + choice of salad ($13.75). I got the trout sandwich and green salad (listed options are potato salad and cole slaw, so you just gotta ask). 

I thought the matzo ball soup was only okay, though that's a popular item here. It has bland flavoring, yet maybe that's how matzo soup is? The sandwich bread was good, and the green salad was fresh with nice dressing. The corn beef and pastrami sandwiches are well known here. 

Order at the counter. The cashier was friendly. There's free samples of rugelach and bread out. Nice decorations and other food/ apparel items to buy. Nice table and seating layout. 

Save your receipt and get $2 off entrance admission to the Contemporary Jewish Museum.
author: Joanna L.

description:
I am a big fan of Wise Sons, and lunch there is usually a special treat. Don't let this review keep you away from them in general.

Today, however, it was raining lightly outside and the inside dining room is closed on Wednesdays (which my companion and I didn't know), so we took our sandwiches back to the office.

Imagine my surprise when my "corned beef" sandwich was pastrami, which I happen to also like, but which is not the same thing. And, if you are an aficionado of Jewish deli, you will imagine my distress at finding cheese (!) on my sandwich. 

It wasn't a Reuben (thank goodness!). I was able to remove the cheese and enjoy the sandwich. But this absolutely wasn't up to Wise Sons' standards. Next time, I'll have to check before I leave the order counter.
author: Debbie N.

description:
The food is overpriced for what it is worth. It is good, but I've had better. The service is also a bit slow... 
I still think Katz Deli in NYC has the most amazing pastrami sandwiches. Wise Sons is a good substitute in the time being in SF but still does not compare to Katz...
author: Janet H.

description: This place should be ashamed of itself to think it's somewhat even close to being a New York Jewish Deli. I grew up in a Jewish Italian neighborhood in The Bronx, New York City where there was at least 2 Kosher Deli's that served Pastrami, Corned Beef Sandwiches and other kosher foods all day long! This place is a total disaster when it comes to authenticity of Jewish cooked foods. The Pastrami and Corned Beef was sliced like prepackaged cold cuts you find in the supermarket- not cut the proper way with a knife. And the utmost sacrilegious thing that could ever happen...they served what they called their chicken soup COLD! I have to say,,,it was the first time in my life that I went to a Jewish deli and did not finish everything that was on my plate! The sandwiches were very small and the service was horrible. Stay away from the not so Jewish Deli that should be called Unwise Sons!
author: Les H.

description: I really liked wise sons! I was surprised some of the reviews were so bad. The cashier was nice and quick. I got the matzo ball soup which was delicious. The matzo ball itself was huge and flavorful. It was nice outside so I sat in their little courtyard and shared my table with a nice older couple. I thought the price was pretty fair for what I got. I was full afterwards from just the soup. Other soups in the area are $6/$7 for a tiny cup. Will be back for sure!
author: Sara T.

description:
I'm still scratching my head and trying to figure out how I just spent over $20 on a 1/2 sandwich & soup.

I came here today for lunch with some co-workers. They had raved about their pastrami and reuben sandwiches. I was intrigued. Unfortunately, what I received was a few measly slices of well-cooked pastrami between two plain pieces of rye bread + a few packets of mustard on the side. I'm not gonna lie - this was a pretty half-ass pastrami sandwich. It came with a crunchy pickle and a side of flavorless potato salad. Don't get me wrong, the pastrami was tasty. But in my experience, Jewish delis usually serve sandwiches where the pastrami is piled sky high. Let's face it - a Jewish deli lives and dies by the quality of its pastrami sandwich.

This tiny sandwich looked like something that a mother would prepare for her 3rd grade son. I don't mean to be dick-ish about this, but I paid $20 for this paltry lunch (and it was literally a few slices of pastrami inserted betwen two small slices of dry, rye bread).
The only redeeming thing about this meal was the Matzo Ball Soup. Wise Sons gives you a hearty bowl of "Jewish penicillin" mixed with generous portions of matso, chicken, & noodles. I think next time I come here, I'll just order the soup and skip out on the sandwich. 

All in all, my lunch was really more of a 2 1/2 star experience. 
Would I return? I guess so (but not in a hurry).
And if I do, it would be for the soup and not the sandwich.
author: Kevin B.

description: Phenomenal pastrami sandwich. Service was mediocre: it was a struggle to get answers to menu questions, food took a while to be served.
author: Kevin V.

description:
I'm Jewish so I feel like it would be rude for me to not like  Jewish Deli, but this place is delicious. The pastrami rueben is on point. Very hearty and filling, nice and salty, melted cheese, nom nom. 

I also got the matzo ball soup which was okay but not the best I've had. It honestly didn't have enough salt. Added the challah french toast which was nothing exciting so I wouldn't do that again.

The potato salad side was a big hit with my parents and sister, as was the cole slaw.

We got a black cherry soda which I haven't had in years and it was sooo delicious.

Overall- big fan if you want a rueben, not as much a fan for matzo ball soup.
author: Jenna G.

description:
I was again craving a nice melty, meaty sandwich. Since I usually take a later lunch, I never get to check out Wise Sons. They close at 2pm. Finally, last week, I made it in time for lunch.

Reuben: pastrami griddled with russian dressing, swiss cheese & sauerkraut on rye ($13.75) add Chopped liver (+$1.50), served with pickles & cole slaw

The sandwich was huge! The pastrami, dressing, cheese and sauerkraut melded together perfectly. I did wish the chopped liver was creamier. It was a little too chunky for me, so it added a weird texture to the sandwich when eating.

The sandwich ended up being $19 with tax and tip. And I only ate half the sandwich. I was a little disappointed with the price, but since I was there, I just said screw it! 4 stars for the sandwich, but bumping down to 3 for the price point.
author: Elena N.

description: Attended the Rube Goldberg exhibit with a couple of friends, and we stopped for lunch afterwards.  We all had the Mushroom Reuben, with coleslaw.  The flavors in the sammie were terrific, though quite greasy (and therefore heavy).  Initially liked the horseradish in the coleslaw, but after a few bites decided it definitely could be dialed back.  Would have given four stars, except we were expected to bus our own dishes, when we'd paid a pretty penny for the food, and there were some young male staffers just kinda hanging around.  And a friend commented that she wasn't comfortable using one of the rest rooms because it was "unpleasant."  (And she's a supremely non-judgemental, tactful person!)  I would perhaps go back here for coffee and rugelach, but would not buy lunch again.  BTW: It's expensive!  With tip, $15 for lunch, with no drink.
author: Karen S.

description:
Perfect for a sunny day lunchtime in SoMA. Not too many of those in SF, but Wise is ready for 'em. 

Fresh ingredients and generous portions of meat or Guac or cheese or mushrooms or whatever the ingredients are a big highlight of their sandwiches. Not at Stage Deli proportions, but they're over the top anyway. 

Food is prepared fast and friendly. 

Honestly, I don't know where you'd fine better potato salad AND cole slaw at one restaurant in the City. Maybe someone bests Wise on potato salad, maybe someone beats Wise on slaw...but best them on both??  Doubt it!!!
author: Lanny B.

description: I was told that the Ruben sandwich here was the best around. Unfortunately I found this to be far from the truth.  Before ordering I asked how long would it take to make a Ruben sandwich because I was on a timed schedule. It took more then double the time.  Sandwich was mediocre and to me not worth the $17 price point nor the 15 min wait but I loved the message on the receipt saying "we are all immigrants." Over all I would not recommend nor would I not return.
author: Daymond D.

description: Go a little off the path for lunch in downtown with the Wise Sons veggie reuben- delicious mushroom substitute for the classic meat. You walk up to a little window on the side of the Jewish museum and they serve you pretty quickly. It's nice to grab a sandwich and eat on the lawn in front of the museum or across the street at Yerba Buena park. Their matzo ball soup is also great!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
The Good: Perfect pastrami sandwiches, on point potato salad, good soft drink selection.

The Bad: $$$.

I went on a pastrami bender. I'm also a reuben snob and a purist enough to believe that its sister sandwich with slaw (named differently everywhere) is a form of heresy.

Wise Sons put me straight.

Their pastrami is legit to the point that you'll be hard pressed to call any pale imitation by the same name. The reuben is a pitch perfect classic, but the #19 is the stuff of dreams. Thick-cut pastrami, slaw, cold Swiss, and great eye bread. Pickle on the side. I am hooked, I think about it around lunch time almost every day, and nothing satisfies the craving like the real deal. Alas, this is an expensive habit.

Yes, they are pricey, especially if you want double meat (not necessary) for a full $8, the price of an entire sandwich elsewhere. BUT, you absolutely get what you pay for in quality. Pickle and slaw or potato salad sides definitely sweeten the deal, and if you have any dough left over there's a good selection of quality soft drinks to wash down that awesome sandwich.

If you love the reuben (corned beef available) or pastrami, or both. You owe yourself a visit to Wise Sons.
author: R. S.

description: Its been a while since I have eaten here, but at some point in the last year or so they seamed to have cheaped out the meat. The pastrami sandwiches used to have great, thick cuts of meat, piled high. I could barely finish one. Now, we have thinner cuts of meat, with less meat. While the sandwiches are still good, the prices remain high, and at $17+ after taxes, I just expect and remember more.
author: Mr. X.

description: Solid salmon bagel with less cream cheese. Avocado comes as spread, not whole. Good pastrami. Will be back.
author: Alison D.

description: They won't serve me. I see two workers at the outside counter and they just look at me. I nicely say hello looking to buy some bagels for the office they both walk away. I say hello and they look out from the back office and run back in. So I guess I was not their target customer and was worthless enough to be ignored. So I left and I was really hoping to get the office some bagels and smear.
author: Eric P.

description:
I had a picnic across the street last week and a friend mentioned the sandwiches were good here. Once I found out the name of the deli I quickly bookmarked it and made my first visit yesterday. 

We walked up to a window and picked up a few menus. My initial thought was feeling overwhelmed with options and didn't know where to start and then I saw the prices. The average price for a sandwich was about $11 which was pretty steep. 

Given that this was my first time I asked the cashier what the best seller was and I wanted that. The cashier was very friendly, helpful and patient with me. I ended up ordering the corn beef Reuben sandwich. My choices of meat were turkey, pastrami and corn beef. The diet conscious me said I should have went with the turkey but the foodie side said "go big or go home" so corn beef it was! The sandwich also came with a side so I got the cole slaw over the potato salad. The sandwich was about $14 and after taxes closer to $16. Yup, $16 bucks for a sandwich. This better be good.

I received my order within 10 minutes. I was anticipating a bigger sandwich for the price but it was pretty normal sized. I admit the Reuben was perfectly toasted and was absolutely delicious, the corn beef was seasoned well, not dry, and every bite left me wanting more. I also love how it came with 2 pieces of pickles for added crunch. 

Overall, loved the sandwich and would like the come back. My only complaint is the price and for $16 I can get dinner to go.
author: Jeanne L.

description: $16.50 for a sandwich. Holy moly! It was a pleasant enough sandwich but I am a bit of a novice when it comes to Reuben's so can't judge it based on previous experience (just previous sandwich experience). But unless the sandwich was actually 2 sandwiches or a full size pizza or a ticket to the movies I can't see where the 16.50 came from. The potato salad was a bit of a miss.
author: Tristan L.

description:
I was really looking forward to a Jewish deli experience coming from New York and missing real deli food in California. First of all it is overpriced, $14 for a medium size pastrami sandwich and $8. for a cup of matzo ball soup. I thought may be worth trying coming from the Jewish Museum. But After 4 hours I'm still dying from salt attack from my pastrami sandwich and scratching my head over the bland soup. The pastrami tasted was more like it was barbecue than any thing I have known as a deli pastrami sandwich. The cuts of meat was thick not thinly sliced melt in your mouth deli style.  
We may have started on the wrong footing when I ordered a combo sandwich and soup. Not being a mayonnaise fan  they offered me a house salad because I didn't want the  coleslaw or potato salad. I find out at the cash register that even though I was not taking the $3. Side I had to pay extra for the salad. There was no way around it as the manager told me it was the restaurant policy. My friend asked for a lean cut and was charged an extra  .50. I passed on the extra lean cut because it wasn't that important to me and I didn't want to give these guys any more of my cash and I ended up getting the exact same cut as she did. My point is that these guys really aren't in the customer care business. For $20+ for a deli lunch you can find a more satisfying meal and I won't be back. I'm going to LA for my next sandwich.
author: Jane C.

description: I LOVE the salmon open-face bagel with everything on it at the stand at the Ferry Building. Do you have this at your Deli behind the Jewish Museum too? I've also had the matzo ball soup (so filling, healthy and yum!) and corned beef sandwich (love this too, keep the fat, love it!). If I need a good, filling meal, especially after I've been to my gym nearby, I keep this place first on my list.
author: Maile N.

description:
Ok, so as a NY Jew who's been eating deli for 50+ years believe me when I tell you that this place is piss poor on virtually every level. 

The litmus test is always a hot pastrami on rye and, to be fair, the rye was excellent, but the pastrami was ultra fatty and the quantity was meager by any standard, especially for the price. 

And if you check my 100+ reviews I'm not a price whiner---I've happily paid $18.95 at all the "name" NY delis for a hot pastrami on rye. 

The thing that really got me was the "fake out" on the size of the sandwich Wise pulls by using an undersized loaf---so while at first glance it looked a bit skimpy, if the rye was a normal circumference it would have been laughably small. 

Last comments: Pickles were crap, cole slaw was crap, sandwich was crap, undersized rye bread was good---net/net a one star. Won't be back.
author: Mike f.

description:
Pastrami sandwich from the take out window, $14. Not worth it in my opinion.

Pastrami is good, but a little salty. Fatty, but wish it were fattier. The sliced rye on which it's served is really good.

Comes with two pickle spears and a choice of potato salad or cole slaw. I had the slaw, which was tasty.

Decent portion, not skimpy, not huge. I finished it all without feeling stuffed afterward.
author: J K.

description: The crispy pastrami and pomegranate seeds on the country Cobb salad is so  delicious!
author: Andrea M.

description: Wow this place has gone down! The place was so dirty with few of the tables cleaned, food all over the floor, empty water tanks, no silverware... I could go on. Food was ok but really a terrible experience. Too much success? Hubris?
author: Philippe S.

description: The only thing keeping me from awarding this place five stars is the loud obnoxious rock music blaring and drowning out any semblance of conversation. Totally wrong for this environment. Owners should make note!
author: Dave M.

description:
Oy!... I vas so vorried that I vas getting a body cavity search since I forgot to floss, you should pardon the expression. I liked it when American Box was here in the CJM for a few months. Nice people, good boxed lunches, and hardly a soul to be found on a weekday. But now that Wise Sons has taken over the space, the place has been discovered by a larger group of hungry goyims, shikshas, and nudniks (photo: http://bit.ly/19Pa3P4). I think Jamie W. and I got all verklempt about it, and how appropriate to have a Jewish-style deli in a Jewish museum. Mazel Tov!... So now that there's a match made in heaven, or at least somewhere near the Lower East Side of Manhattan, I can die a happy man after getting a little nosh here.

But first there's the security gate to overcome. I had to empty out all my pockets...my keys, my wallet, my loose change, my vibrating egg, nothing was sacred to this man. In fact, we'll be going out on our first date soon. I filled up his Tupperware container quite easily. Good thing he wasn't asking for a urine sample, too. Once you pass, no small feat, mind you, there was another line to contend with on this busy Saturday morning. The menu is small, but all the sandwiches you would expect in a Jewish deli are accounted for...pastrami, corned beef, brisket. Egg creams? Check. Rugelach? Check. Chinese chicken salad? Of course...what do you expect my Aunt Sylvia to eat? She's gotten a little hippy after grazing the buffet line in the Catskills.

We thought we were going to challish waiting to order. Jamie went for his favorite, a $12 Corned Beef Reuben prepared on a griddle with Russian dressing, Swiss cheese and sauerkraut (photo: http://bit.ly/13PhTAU). This was no chazzerai, it was geshmak... I mean delicious. My order was also geshmak. It was the $10.50 Classic Roast Brisket on Rye. I read previous Yelp reviews and knew to be very specific that I wanted lettuce, tomato and mayonnaise...yes, mayonnaise...in my sandwich (photo: http://bit.ly/1be8JmJ). So our one complaint was that these were California portions meaning they were kinda on the paltry side for our voracious appetites. Don't expect the heaping mounds you see at Katz's, Carnegie, or even Miller's East Coast Deli, but then again, these aren't as pricey neither.

We decided to share a $7 bowl of Matzoh Ball Soup, which contains one of the biggest matzohs I've seen since Aunt Sylvia made me look at the boil on her toochis (photo: http://bit.ly/17z1aTI). The broth was quite hearty, and there was real chicken in there. I felt my own toochis grow by a foot, I swear, and this wasn't even technically our first visit. Get avay you say! Yes, we came here the day before to try the takeout window since the inside was packed. All we had room for were a couple of Rugelach - soft and yummy (photo: http://bit.ly/1ceCUhy) and a slice of the Cinammon Babka - something sweet but a little stale if you should pardon the expression (photo: http://bit.ly/18cpBZr). If it's good enough for Woody...

FOOD - 4 stars...nice quality deli fare that a mommala would love though portions are skimpy if you know what I mean
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...it's the lobby of the Contemporary Jewish Museum...what better setting for a Jewish deli?
SERVICE - 3 stars...a bit stressed
TOTAL - 4 stars...get a nosh here, couldn't hurt...shalom!
author: Ed U.

description:
Pros: Quality of the ingredients is pretty good. Corned beef tasted pretty much as I remembered it from my childhood and NYC visits. Rye bread soft on the inside, crunchy on the outside. Matzoh ball soup was an accurate rendition, a little bland compared to the chicken soup you're probably used to from the can or supermarket (those are overly salted, etc) but this is essentially what my Mom makes.

Cons: You have to go through security to get inside. While it's light security, that's still a lot of friction to get a lox and bagel. Fortunately you can also order the full menu at the walkup window outside. Prices are steep, two soups and two sandwiches cost me $37! And the portion sizes aren't NYC sized, you don't get a heaping pound of corned beef on that sandie. 

Since I do like Jewish comfort food like nobody's business, I'll be back.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I got a vegetarian reuben. I'd never seen one of those before, and so they get points for that. And I really wanted to like it. 

The bread was great, but my bottom slice was soggy even though I ate it there. The mushrooms had all but slid out of the sandwich. Clearly a construction problem, maybe their chief sandwich engineer was out for the day and the kids were running awry. 

The potato salad was good, better than average, but not very interesting. 

And the place is overpriced. There are at least 5 spots I'd go to again in the area, but sadly, this is not one of them...
author: Dimple B.

description: Great breakfast find. We had the egg sandwich with pastrami bacon and avocado. Excellent. Be sure to grab some napkins, the sandwich can get messy waking around the market. Will go again and try the other options.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Conveniently located near office and hotel, Wise Sons first caught my eye for their pleasing branding (I'm a sucker for typography!) and speedily became a go-to spot for lunch during my recent time in San Francisco. 

After a few solid days of work trip eating, ordering the Matzo Ball Soup was the simple nourishment I needed. Granted, similar to other reviewers comments it was considered a little bland by my dining companions, however, at that point in time I wasn't chasing bold flavours so it did the trick for this weary traveller. A few days later when I returned for a "I forgot to eat breakfast, I'm so hungry" lunch my classic pastrami sandwich combo with potato salad was equally fresh and tasty.  

Jewish delis aren't something you can get a lot of in Australia so dining at Wise Sons' was a welcome introduction a cuisine I'm eager to learn more about!
author: Lani P.

description: I got a pastrami and a corned beef Reuben. They were both excellent. Homemade juicy meats with great kraut and potato salad. I would pay $15 again for such a great sandwich.
author: Philip M.

description:
Food here is basic. My firm caters lunch every Friday and one Friday, we catered here. Their sandwiches are probably the most basic sandwiches I've ever eaten. It was literally meat and bread, no mayonnaise, no mustard, no lettuce, nothing. 

I honestly could've made a better sandwich myself. Don't bother.

1 star for the food.
author: Johnny G.

description:
Great little place to grab a bite, sit inside or out. Service is minimal. Walkup order, take a number style.  Selection of meat style nice but only one kind of bread.  Sodas are mixed flavors. Service people are nice and very sincere.   It's clean inside and comfortable as part of the museum 
It's right across Metreon and they are open on weekends!
author: Brian W.

description: Pretty great sandwiches but like the other reviewers say it's just too expensive for a casual takeout lunch spot, but maybe passable for dine in. The reuben sandwich is pretty great whether it's pastrami or corned beef and the rye bread is amazing, especially with the caraway seeds. I used to eat this kind of bread fresh as a kid and it brought back those memories for sure! One annoying thing is that I find the reuben sandwich by itself quite filling and after tax you're paying like $17 which comes with a side potato salad, which I don't have close to any room for. I'd rather pay $1 or $2 less and not get the potato salad. Oh well. I also overheard others in line raving about the smoked trout sandwich so I'll have to try that next and report back!
author: Andrew D.

description:
Good food. Potato salad was good
Reuben was great but pricey for the size
Desserts were decent
Matzo soup was very good
Outdoor patio
Inside the Jewish contemporary museum
author: Jones T.

description: My boyfriend and I shared a large serving of the French toast, and a cream soda and a coke. $22.
author: Liz C.

description: Good Kosher food in Soma! The pastrami & corned beef sandwiches are good. Also the matzo ball soup is pretty good. Maybe because there really isn't much competition with really no other Jewish Kosher places around in San Francisco. Not sure if it would exactly be on par with places in NY. Kind of expensive, especially for lunch. But if you want Kosher in SF, this is pretty much one of your only options and it's not bad.
author: Peter K.

description: Food is fantastic! The service is excellent especially considering how busy they are. It's a little small but worth the wait. The Wise Sons should take their show on the road. Their cuisine would do well any place in the country.
author: Joe M.

description:
Come here when you're in the mood for a sandwich! You can't go wrong because they're all good. There are pastrami, corned beef, and turkey for the classics (with a mix of sauces and cheese) and specialty sandwiches. 

My favorite is their open-faced smoked salmon bialy. I had my first bialy at the Ferry Building's Wise Sons and it was wonderful. Had the same experience at this Wise Sons. Bialys taste so much better than regular dense bagels. So much that I never want to eat bagels again. The bialy is thin and crisp on the edges. Lesson of the day, bagels are boiled and then baked but bialys skip the boiling step. The smoked salmon bialy was also not plastered with cream cheese and there's enough smoked salmon so you're not wondering where everything went halfway through. Smoked salmon never gets old so if anything I'll be returning for that. 

I also got a chance to try my first and only matzo ball soup so far. The soup was a little salty and the matzo was soft. I'm not sure what it's supposed to taste like so I can't speak much to it. However, the soup was a good pairing with our classic pastrami sandwich. 

Oh funny thing, you do need to pass through security before getting to the cafe and ordering. If you want to eat in their outdoor seating area, you have to get your order to-go. 

Wise Sons was surprisingly empty on a Saturday. I'd imagine it to be more crowded. The location is hidden inside the museum so if you don't know what you're looking for you're going to miss it. 

5 stars for the smoked salmon bialy and 4 stars for everything else! Check this place out! There's no excuse not to since it's conveniently located next to Yerba Buena, the mall, the Metreon and a close walking distance from the Powell station.
author: Ingrid C.

description: Fantastic sandwiches, delicious corned beef and the best potato salad ever! The applesauce with the latkes is tart, sweet and perfect. The matzoh ball soup is solid and I love that they use fresh dill. Have only had carry out so can't comment on service.
author: emily b.

description: Unbelievable! Wise Sons charges $44 per pound for trout salad. That's more than Russ and Daughters in the lower East side charges for their best nova. Only in San Francisco!
author: linda g.

description: Ordered the mushroom reuben and wasn't a big fan. It had an overly strong smoky and salty flavor. Given the lack of veggie options, I won't be coming back.
author: Joshua R.

description:
Many reliable choices at a decent price.
Ambience: Fairly basic seating inside (which you get to through the museum and metal detector entrance). Order at the counter and have it delivered to your table in a basic cafeteria setting. Ordering from the outside is grab and go through a window to the street.
Service: Friendly people and you can watch the prep which is pretty fast.
Food: I was at a conference across the road and went here a few times. Nice lox bagels and reuben (thought it did come with perhaps a little too much butter on the outside which made it oily to handle). One stand-out was a vegetarian reuben which feature trumpet mushrooms as the "meat". This was a bit of a revelation (especially since the typical go-to mushroom would be portobellos). It was original and tasty.
Price: About the same as the other deli/luncheon options nearby.
I like it - the food is fresh and what they do, they do very well.
author: Geoff A.

description: Really? Ordered a pastrami sandwich for to go. The sandwich was at least 50% fat... I had to pick out all the fat because I was so disgusted, and by the time I was done... the sandwich was tiny! Hopefully the picture I upload is attached to this review... terrible. Was recently in NYC and had delicous Katz's deli... came back craving more pastrami... big mistake coming here. Will NOT BE BACK.
author: John D.

description: The mushroom Ruben sounded great, but somewhere they managed to find the toughest, most leathery mushrooms I'd ever encountered. If you can't find edible shrooms you should take the item off your menu -- for a day, a week, or until you can find a good supplier. Definitely not worth waiting in the long line for this.
author: Terry S.

description:
When my fiance and I decided to travel to SF, we wanted to make the most of our trip since it was only a short 3-day vacation so we had to ration our tummy space wisely. Our first stop was a small deli located in The Contemporary Jewish Museum. You wouldn't think there's a sandwich place there...

The pastrami was delicious. It was moist and very well-seasoned. The added coleslaw gave it such a refreshing balance. One thing that I am so surprised at is how delicious the potato salad turned out! I'm from down South and I could've sworn we did it best, but this potato salad reminded me of my childhood and how my dad's friends would always bring us potato salad, because they knew I loved it! Food is always the best when it evokes childhood memories..

The restaurant is quite small and not many seats are available. I would even recommending taking the food outdoors and eating on the steps, if the weather permits. We chose to bring our sandwiches to our next destination, Papa Beard (post coming soon), for dessert. I would love to try the Hot Corned Beef next, but we had to ration our stomach space for other restaurants this time around. I will definitely be back, and hopefully, we can explore the museum too!
author: Leslie L.

description: Been to both locations now, the quality of food here is amazing. The prices are also what you'd expect to pay for the best in NYC (Katz's). The pastrami here is very good, not quite Katz, but still good. The Rye break they make themselves is amazingly good. Portions are on the small side, especially for the prices.
author: Jonah K.

description: They should be embarrassed serving the corned beef sandwhich they pass off for fourteen dollars.  The meat was so fatty that the sandwhich was almost inedible.  Why was that?  Well, let's see, when you cook brisket or corned beef, the fat comes out slowly by cooking for a long time.   To get more of the meat you cook it for less time, it's cheaper that way.  This was probably the worst sandwhich I have had in San Francisco.  The rye bread they put it on was excellent and so was the pickle however this is is not a real deli and certainly has nothing to do with the great New York places like Katz's and 2nd Avenue deli.  Only the most jaded hipster could like this poor quality, overpriced place.  And, the folks working there hated being there, which is never a good sign.
author: Bill S.

description:
A perfect weekday lunch includes taking my pup for a stroll on the dog-friendly lawns in front of the Contemporary Jewish Museum - it's a win-win because he gets to say hello to his four-legged friends, and I get to order kosher meats at Wise Sons' walk-up window!

So I'm about to tell you to spend $15 on a sandwich (yes, just ONE) but I promise you won't be mad at me. The #19 beckons to be savored bite-by-bite with its layers of smoky pastrami, cole slaw, Russian dressing, and Swiss cheese on overachieving rye bread (it boasts the most satisfying crunchy crust yet it's still pillowy soft on the inside).

The sandwich is actually $13.75, but once tax is added, you're looking at a $15 investment. However, you won't be looking at it for very long - it's so good that there's nothing else to do but devour it.

Buh bye, $15... you sure were delicious.
author: Jelena Z.

description: First, I am from The East Coast. I did not think that there was a Jewish Deli west of The Mississippi. For a while, I was right. Then, I found Max's Cafe at Opera Plaza. Second, a friend of mine took me to The Jewish Museum (the jew mue). We had a very disappointing and overpriced lunch at Wise's. My order took twice as long as everyone else's at the table. The potato salad was tasteless. I have had better from Safeway. My pickles were have the size of others. On the upside, the club looked great and the service was excellent; these guys really hustle. My advise.... go to Max's and get a real tasty, large sandwich. Tell them I sent you.
author: Jan N.

description:
The food here is great, if you love the simplicity of the classic Jewish deli.

It is Friday today and unfortunately they have only one clerk taking orders....for 30 folks both inside and outside. The line is about 20 minutes long! Bummer to have to wait so long for great food!

Thumbs kinda up...mixed review here.
author: Jessica B.

description:
No matter what my request (lean, please) the corned beef sandwich arrived greasy and fatty. Fortunately it appeared tucked into the most terrific rye bread. Their matzoh ball soup is still very good and they serve a really big bowl with the Downtowner Special. You might try their excellent egg cream soda while declining the tasteless coleslaw.

It's nice to sit on the patio outside the Jewish Museum near the financial district. I'll probably try the chopped liver half sandwich next time.
author: Lynn S.

description:
perfect hangover cure. hands down. my friends and I woke up last weekend after the second day of outside lands and were not in the best shape to say the least. my roommate suggested we order wise sons for delivery. best advice she's ever had. 

I ordered a pastrami and egg breakfast sandwich with matzo ball soup. the matzah ball soup was to die for - maybe one of the best matzah ball soups i've ever had. It tasted fresh and something your mother or grandmother would cook. it was the perfect meal. We also all shared the pastrami cheese fries which were amazing too. 

My 2 friends ordered the bagel and lox which I tried a few bites of and it was SO YUMMY. take my word for it. anything you get there is going to be a party in your mouth. might become a bit dangerous considering they deliver....hmmm oh well. 

The delivery did take about an hour which was a struggle but won't stop me from ordering again and again! just keep that in mind when ordering.
author: Ilana B.

description: Still the best deli in Northern California. Their interpretation of the tradition is all new. Now with bialy and bagel bakery...wow.
author: Fred  D.

description:
This Wise Son's location is great (as well as their other locations).  The bialys are awesome and you can even get an order to go (usually they are on the shelf pre ordering or ask if they are not there).

Trout sandwich is great! The PLT (pastrami lettuce tomato) special is phenomenal!

Often I request the bialy for the smoke salmon open face sandwich and/or trout sandwich.

Always love going there.
author: Ben J.

description:
A great spot for lunch...and an afternoon snack. 

For lunch, I shared the #19 with a friend and got a matzo ball soup. I love the matzo ball soup - rich, delicious chicken soup with a matzo ball that can hold its own. The #19 was also good (a lot of meat on the sandwich) but the soup is my favorite. It's a pricey lunch but worth it for a bit of a splurge (lunch will run you about $15). You can either enter through the museum to dine indoors or get takeaway from the window.

I also love their chocolate babka which for me, is eaten as an afternoon snack. Maybe with their lemonade (which is excellent).
author: Wendy L.

description: Best Ruben ever! It takes a minute to wait inline because this place is so popular, but it's well worth the wait. The (limited) outdoor seating is pretty fun too.
author: Chad R.

description: Yes, it's a bit pricey, but *very* good.  Compared to a full sandwich ($14), the Soup and 1/2 sandwich ($14) option is a better value = big bowl of soup (not a small cup), heaping bowl of slaw or potato salad, 2 pickles and a reasonable sized 1/2 sandwich (if you have room for it)!  I made room for chocolate Babka & coffee...oh my, both delicious!
author: Brook H.

description: I love Pastrami sandwich but for $14?  It was ok but for takeout?  Come on!!!  I may be back if I'm sooo wanting for the taste but I have found other places for less that will not leave me hungry.
author: Jay S.

description:
It's not bad food; it's just not worth it for the price.

$15 for a classic sandwich (with no add-ons) with scarce meat (esp for a jewish delicatessen), iced tea or lemonde and cole slaw or potato salad.  they provide dijon mustard and ketchup on the table.  i'll passsssss.

also, prepare to take your keys / phone out of your pockets and have your backpack searched because there's security at the "jewseum" (their words not mine)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
TL;DR: You'd be wise not to go here, son.

I was pretty excited to try the much-hyped Wise Sons.  I had this idea that it would be like Katz's in NYC.  Wow, what a profound disappointment.

We got a pastrami sandwich combo, a bialy with smoked salmon, and a diet cola (Boylan's, of course - far be it from the Wise Sons to offer such lowly fare as Diet Coke).  And that was over $30!  Massively overpriced.

The portions were paltry, to say the least.  It wasn't anywhere near the NYC Katz's - even the Katz's Bagels a block down Mission St. is better.  The pastrami sandwich in particular was mighty thin.  I actually left hungry and had to go get something else to eat.

As for the quality, even that was "meh."  The pastrami is better and cheaper at the Golden Gate Meat Company in the Ferry Building, and served in much more copious quantities to boot.  The smoked salmon is better at Whole Foods.  Just a weak showing overall.  I won't be back.
author: Marco C.

description:
Beautiful little deli inside the Jewish Museum. I had been to the original location in the Mission, and this one is an easy walk from my house.

Their reuben....unbelievable. And you have to order the potato salad. Have to. 

They are super friendly as well. Clean restaurant, beautiful architecture of the building. Just a nice experience.
author: Amy O.

description:
I literally salivate just thinking of Wise Sons.

I live in NY and am from LA, so I know a good deli when I eat at one, and Wise Sons simply does it right.

What they do so well is take the familiar flavors and techniques from your old Jewish grandmother, and sneak in something else -- a dish never veers from its familiar flavor profile or disrespects your palette...but the team at Wise Sons just seems to be able to add something special.

I think it's heart.
Delicious, mouth-watering heart.
author: Shana B.

description:
They serve an amazing pastrami reuben. Thick slices of spiced meat with plenty of fat and juices topped with melted cheese. The rye bread is toasted crispy and topped with the perfect amount of sauerkraut. Paired with a side of coleslaw, you've got yourself a delicious meal.

$19 for the sandwich, side and a soda is little on the pricier side, but no regrets today. This is a great place for a lunch date with the pup in the courtyard at the Jewish museum. Give it a try!
author: Vince L.

description:
Quick bite for two during a Moscone convention break.

Open faced salmon sandwich was fine.  Nothing to write home about.
Pastrami sandwich had meager portions, no offering of sauce or slaw, and was too 'smokey'
Not coming back,
author: Bill H.

description:
So disappointing ... I am giving 2 stars only because the pastrami, or what I got of it, was very good, as was the cole slaw.  But the service and general food quality at the CJM location of Wise Sons was a huge let-down.
