To start, we arrived around 12:30 on Saturday and it wasn't crowded. There were two parties ahead of us in line, but it took like 20 minutes to get our order in. The lone woman at the register also had to deal with problems in the kitchen getting orders right and take out. The party ahead of us was 7 people, which certainly wasn't her fault, but their ordering was painfully slow. When we finally did order, I noted that, instead of just giving me a tea bag and a cup, she had to open the bag and prepare the tea herself--a huge time waste when there was now a lengthy wait. This is just a minor annoyance that  I would recommend eliminating. People can pour their own hot water into a cup. 

The real disappointment was the food. It was apparent that there were some problems with food orders, as several plates appeared to be going back. There were only two guys behind the counter. As a New Yorker, I relish a good pastrami sandwich. Wise Sons bills Hot Pastrami. We ordered a sandwich and a kale Caesar.  After waiting another 20+ minutes, the food came. The sandwich contained maybe 3 slices of fatty, not hot or even warm pastrami.  I wish I had taken it back, but we were now running late and it already had taken about 45 minutes in a not-crowded cafe. I had asked for the salad tossed;  instead the dressing came on the side and there wasn't enough to cover. It was bland.  The cole slaw was tasty. 

 Bottom line,  $13.50 for a deli sandwich warrants a decent sandwich, with an adequate portion of meat. The pastrami was meager and about 30% fat, both of which are unacceptable. The service was slow and inefficient.    Reputation for good food isn't enough, guys.
author: Joyce H.

description:
bad - do not cater from here, they are disorganized and ruined our company lunch with a ton of stuff missing from our order.  

to top it off, the management did a poor job in reacting to their mistake.
author: Mel D.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here - I got the Rueben (w/ Corned Beef) and it was tender and moist and full of flavor...the sandwich was great.  I also ordered a side of Potato salad, which was good and a Chocolate Babka, which was surprisingly good...even though the bread was a bit dry (typical for Babka), the soft chocolate really helped to balance out the texture...the chocolate itself was very good and decadent.
 
Definitely a great place to eat in the area (you don't have to pay for entrance into the museum to enjoy a meal here)...they also have some outside seating which is great on a nice day.
author: Ken G.

description: I've only gone to the location in The Mission, so I can't speak to the others. The food here NEVER disappoints. It's really incredible and consistent---and a good portion. The service, on the other hand, is always lacking. The last time I was in here recently, one of the staff actually less than subtly nudged us on our way. Seemed we were taking too long finishing up. He made an offhanded comment that suggested that at least. And actually, I'd always wondered why this place wasn't rated better--then this happened, and I clued into why.
author: Alexa M.

description:
I've had reubens throughout the country and have pretty strong opinions on what it should taste like. Before coming here the best was by far Langer's in LA and a distant 2nd was Kenny and Zukes in Portland. Sorry Katz Deli, you are a charlatan and an embarrassment to sandwiches. If I wanted a hot dog tasting reuben I would have ordered a hot dog.

Anyway, I can firmly say Wise Son's reuben is in my top 3, not #1 however. The smokey flavor and tenderness of the meat was very nice and tasted like a top tier sandwich. I was rather happy afterwards.

On the other hand, the veggie reuben my spouse had was too strong with the smokey flavor and the mushrooms were a bit too tough.
author: Josh E.

description:
Only go if you're prepared to wait over ten minutes in a line then another twenty for your order to come up in their so called "take out window"

Ordered the downtown special. Shouldn't you have some of those kinda ready to go? Downtown people are on the move not wanting to awkwardly wait in the cold listening to weird small talk from museum goers and tourists.

Food - sandwich is half of a sandwich but I'd say it's more of a half of a half a sandwich. Tiny!!! Matzah ball soup is water with uncooked carrots some chicken and a huge rock hard matzah ball. 

So much fail.

Not worth the stress and wasting half my lunch break and my money.

#neveragain
author: Kendra S.

description:
Vegetarian Jewish food lovers rejoice! The vegetarian Reuben is here to satisfy your every desire. Smokey, tender mushrooms surrounded by tangy sauerkraut, Russian dressing, and perfectly melted Swiss, all on nicely toasted rye. Put some well-flavored potato salad on the side and to me it's the best lunch I've had in a long time. The wife and I shared a house made lemonade that was perfectly sweet and lemony. 
This place is known for quality and they have not disappointed me. Quality service and top quality food.  
All in all, five stars all around.
author: adam t.

description: I came here with my co-workers upon recommendation. I got the classic corned beef on their double baked rye. I've never had anything so delicious in my life! The corned beef was so moist and the bread was so flavorful. I really enjoyed the cole slaw that came with it as well. It had a great punch of mustard and the cabbage was fresh and crunchy. My only complaint is the price. The price is pretty steep for the size of the sandwich. I also wish the bread was toasted -- perhaps they would if you ask. Regardless, Wise Sons has my vote for one of the best sandwiches in the SoMa area.
author: Hana K.

description: Great Jewish deli food. The reuben sandwich, potato salad and motza ball soup (with noodles inside) were all solid choices. Sat outside on their tables. Will be back.
author: Jones J.

description: Can't go wrong with pastrami on rye at Wise Sons.  Great bagel. Excellent chocolate babka.
author: Bleep S.

description:
Bread. 
While its not all about the bread with any given sandwich - the bread will make or break this food form.

The double baked rye makes the WS Rueben with hot corned beef - a case study in what a traditional sando should be.

All the ingredients were nothing short of delicious - and overall experience was one id recommend.
Havent tried their pastrami, but having recently come back from NYC - I cant wait to compare it to the pastrami at https://www.yelp.com/biz/pastrami-queen-new-york
author: Oleg H.

description: Had the pastrami Reuben. It was solid. Potato salad was amazing. Pickles were good. Double baked rye was off the charts. High price. And it's no Katz. But for west coast, it's pretty solid.
author: Knolan H.

description:
First of all--any of you complaining about the prices here have obviously not been to a Jewish deli in an Eastern city like NYC or Cleveland. These are bargain deals at Wise Sons! And please keep in mind that many people have to travel hundreds to miles to find a real deli.

Secondly, the matzoh ball soup is awesome. Hearty but not heavy, with a huge matzoh ball, noodles, and plenty of chicken & sliced carrots. Plus it's not overly salty. Share a bowl and a sandwich with someone you care about.

My girlfriend liked her egg cream, and I enjoyed half a chopped liver sandwich. Yes, the sandwich could have used more liver, but it was tasty and filling. The rye bread was the best I've had in years--crisp crust, fresh insides--yum! Our potato salad and cole slaw were above average. Service was good, and while the ambiance is a bit industrial, the space, with every table occupied, was surprisingly quiet and peaceful.

The only miss was the vegetarian Reuben sandwich. It was tasty, but the smoked shitake mushrooms were a bit tough and maybe a tad too smoky. The other ingredients on the sandwich were excellent. 

I'm a fan!
author: J R.

description:
This is not my first time around the block with the Wise Sons. I've gone to their pop-up at the Ferry building a few times and have had breakfast at their flagship on 24th street (it wasn't so good). I've been impressed with the sandwiches and the amount of meat I'd had on the first couple, but each experience since has gotten skimpier.

Today a co-worker and I decided to trek down to the Ferry Building for some Jewish comfort food, with the holiday beginning tonight an all, and right where Wise Sons was supposed to be was a vacant plot. Had we missed the exodus?

So, we popped onto MUNI and made our way to the takeout window at the Jewish Contemporary Museum. Apparently we weren't the only ones who had decided that jew food was a necessity today. The line was long. Not 'fleeing Egypt' long, but enough to discourage you on your average 60 minute lunch break.

We persevered!

It took about a half hour to get to the window and order, which was fine and expected, and after another 20-30 minutes my co-worker got her food (a much larger, more complex order than mine). Then about 7 people who were behind me got their food (I see from other reviews that this is not an unusual occurrence with these "wise" guys). After I inquired what was holding them up, I was told, "Oh, it's coming." 3 orders later I got my bag, I asked where my soda was, got it, and we were off, back to work.

I got to my desk, opened my lunch in anticipation and realized immediately that they had not put coleslaw on my #19. Granted, I asked for it on the side (so it wouldn't get the bread soggy before I got back to my desk), but it was just not there. I prayed for it, and nuthin.

The worst part about this is that my lunch came to about $19.21 (plus I gave them a tip).

I ordered:

1 #19, basically a warm ruben with coleslaw instead of sauerkraut that came with a side of potato salad (plus add $1.00 for ordering lean meat)
1 Cream Soda

If the sandwich was grand, with more meat than I could eat in a single sitting, fine. But this pitiful sandwich wouldn't be out of place at a Lee's lunch counter. The meat is better quality, of course, but the portion was literally laughable. They put 3 moderately sized slices of corned beef on the sandwich and called it a day. Compared to every other jewish delicatessen I've been to in my life, this was literally the smallest portion of meat I've ever seen on a sandwich. Their ancestors would be aghast! 

I love my people's food, but this is the last time Wise Sons is getting my money. 

NOT WORTH IT. NOT MENSCHES. NOT GOING BACK.
author: J. Scott H.

description:
It took far too long, but Jen & I finally made it to Wise Sons, in the Contemporary Jewish Museum.  I feel like a fool. It was absolutely fantastic!
I felt like I was back in New York City, sitting in a small, nice cafeteria in the tasteful museum setting. Order at the cashier, find a table, and a short wait for two "classic" pastrami sandwiches to be delivered.  And what sandwiches- lean pastrami, wonderfully spiced and piled high ( but not ridiculously so) on a perfect corn rye (baked on site) for me, fresh-baked challah for the wife's sandwich.  Not fatty at all - it was miles above the bacon-striped peppered slices most west coasters usually serve.
A fine house made potato salad...no, make that a perfect potato salad, and two very good pickle slices completed the sandwich plates.
There are not enough stars in the SF nite sky for this meal.  Thank you, Wise Sons!!!
author: Brian B.

description:
I'm no corned beef connoisseur, but I can tell you when I've had a good sandwich, and I definitely did at Wise Sons! I ordered the #19 with corned beef. It's got "cold swiss", which meant swiss that isn't melted, like straight out of the fridge. I liked the contrasting texture, although it was a little surprising at first. 

The best part of my lunch was the potato salad, which is abso-freaking-lutely amazing!! Seriously, I would just come here for a tub of potato salad if they have it. (Do they have it?) If given the option between the cole slaw and the potato salad... GO WITH POTATO!
author: Virginia T.

description:
Hot pastrami and swiss sandwich was awesome (no saurkraut for me).  Potato salad was very good.  Egg salad sandwich was so so.

Overall a nice lunch.  Just have to ignore the prices.  It's a museum after all.
author: Lewis C.

description: What a great paring, Wise Sons Jewish deli and the CJM! I ordered the corned beef sandwich and my girlfriend ordered the whitefish sandwich. Hers came about ten minutes before mine, so she was almost finished by the time my sandwich arrived. My sandwich was a real disappointment. The bread to filling ratio was about equal, which I could have excused had the corned beef been moist and tender. Instead I almost chocked on my first bite, which was mostly fat. Now I'm used to a little fat, but this was excessive. I eventually opened the sandwich and carved away what amounted to half the contents, which was inedible. When I showed the counterman, he said that they aim for20% fat content , but this was closer to 50%. They offered me nothing in why of putting things right. Maybe my expectation were too high for a mini version of a deli inside a museum, but, based on this experience I am reluctant to try the other, full size branches.
author: Nick S.

description:
I'm in SF, CA for a conference at an over-priced hotel on 4th street. The conference offered lunch at the exhibit floor with such treats as $9 hot dogs. Sorry, I came here for the meeting and the food. 
Right outside the back door of the hotel is the Contemporary Jewish Museum, and at the back of the museum is a deli, which is also accessible through a take-out window. So far, my 3 favorite things about Wise Sons are:
1) they brine and smoke their own meats
2) they bake their own bread
3) they brine and smoke their own meats
I got the Pastrami on rye, the "classic," which comes with cole slaw (or potato salad). As others (e.g. Matt O.) have commented, the sandwich is not huge, but I will gladly surrender the quantity for this quality. It was plenty for lunch. The meat was piled about an inch thick and was fall-apart tender. This was superb pastrami, and the bread was all one could ask. 
Is $13 a lot for a sandwich and slaw? Not compared to $8 hot dogs. I went a little before noon, so (with no line) had a chance to chat with the nice lady at the window and got a little of the back-story on the place. Do take up the conversation if you have the opportunity. (Your bubbie would be happy.)
author: David R.

description:
Yummmmm! I had the hot corned beef sandwich, with a side of coleslaw and a pickle. Was so delicious and not over the top with the meat, just the right amount. My son had the grilled cheese sandwich and a side of potato salad. He love them both and ate half the sandwich and most of the potato salad (he is only two so that was a sign of how good it was!)

There were several homeless people perusing the bin of the front for leftovers which is perhaps indicative of the generous serving size and reputation?!

We ordered from the outside window and ate outside so I can't really comment on the service - the lady who served us a the window got the job done fine, but wasn't as friendly other service I received in the US.
author: Alison M.

description: At the urging of a friend, I recently made a return visit, and had a pastrami sandwich, with some matzoh ball soup. The meat on the sandwich was much better than on my previous visit, but was still poorly trimmed, with a fairly small portion. The soup was fine, but not as good as Max's. Service was friendly.
author: Jethro B.

description: I was excited to try some authentic Jewish deli cuisine! While this place was tasty, it didn't really wow me. A little on the expensive side (oy vay, am I right?) and nothing that blew my taste buds out of the water. The pickles were just OK. Definitely gets the job done, but definitely not NY quality.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
Corned beef. So good. Buy it. And order ahead of time to avoid a line.

Matzo ball soup was pretty good, but I've had too many homemade versions to make a fair judgement.
author: Matt W.

description:
I ordered a reuben with coleslaw from the take-out window. I work a block away and this would be a convenient spot for lunch. 

My order took about 5 minutes, which is reasonable. 

The reuben was one of the better reubens I've ever tasted, however I was a little disappointed by the portion size, the sandwich wasn't particularly large. I did like that choices were provided between pastrami and corned beef. The slaw was above average. 

I might do this again, but the $15 price for a reuben is pretty high. I would do this on a regular basis if it were max $11.
author: Matt O.

description: Very good corned beef sandwich and hubby got pastrami.  Both very authentic and tasty.  Potato salad had a lot of onion which I am not personally a fan of but it was good.  Nice dill pickle spear with the huge sandwich.  A little pricey in my opinion but I am from the midwest.
author: Nicole D.

description:
This review deals with lunch!

First, let me tell you about the positives here:
    - the sandwiches here ARE pretty good
    - The cashiers are usually personable

Alright, that's about it. The wait for a sandwich here is interminable --- you can expect to pay around $15 and wait anywhere between 5 and 40 minutes for your food. In my case, I watched half a dozen people who ordered after me get their grub before I did! 

Although the sandwiches are good, they are neither $15 good nor 40-minute-wait good, even though they come with potato salad or coleslaw (also decent, but you can't forgo this side to reduce the cost). I'd recommend going somewhere else for lunch if you're after a good sandwich (perhaps Sentinel, ~2 blocks away), unless you have a lot of time to potentially kill or were going to visit the Contemporary Jewish Museum anyway.
author: Haak S.

description:
It's super hard for me to give five stars to a hipster laden place that serves a $15.00, not particularly large sandwich, to go from a take out window, but geez their corned beef Rueben is just so yummy, perfectly griddled with crispy edged cheesy goodness. Their tiny compostable container of cold potato salad that accompanies the fifteen dollar (with tax) sandwich is perfect, slightly tangy dressing, soft but not mushy potatoes. 

In all fairness I could go inside the deli thru the museum doors, order and eat at an actual table but sometimes the line to get past security is just too long.
author: Poppy C.

description: Overpriced for what you get, note the picture of a $14 small sandwich and potato salad. Enough said.
author: Jeff W.

description: What a hidden gem. This place is NOT overrun and offers high quality Jewish comfort food - with an organic flair - in a great location conducive to conversation. Other than having to go through a metal detector, all was great. My cobb was excellente, especially that bacon-like fried pastrami. MMMMM.
author: Andrew K.

description: Amazing Reuben sandwich. It's just so tasty! Price is little high but definitely worth it! Only downside  is that if you want to sit inside of the store you have to go through the security??!! Definitely not convenient when you are on your lunch break!
author: Karolina C.

description:
Something special.

Listed as a specialty sandwiches the smoked Diestel turkey, avocado spread, honey mustard, pickled onions and greens on whole wheat was special indeed.

An impressive amount of flavor was in each bite taken on this particularly impressive April day. Inside seating is closed on Wednesdays. We'd have been outside anyway.

Service is straightforward out of a window (at least on Wednesdays) and on point Appreciated getting more pickles instead of cole slaw or potato salad.

Holding back that elusive fifth star is the price. For $12 it should be this good. 

Four stars doesn't make it any less special.
author: Jason B.

description:
Disappointing

I had the half-sandwich and matzoh ball soup combo. The sandwich came on excellent rye bread, but the pastrami was so heavily smoked that it tasted more like barbecue than brined meat. The matzoh ball soup, which Wise Sons says is "not as good as your bubbe's," was indeed not as good as my bubbe's. The broth was bland (though there was plenty of it, since the soup came in a full bowl-size container, rather than a cup-size container), and the matzoh ball had an off flavor. The pickles that came with the sandwich were likewise unremarkable, and the potato salad, though tasty, couldn't redeem the meal. Others may like these flavors, but other than the bread, this lunch didn't really say "Jewish Deli" to my taste buds.
author: Z K.

description: Wise Sons is a great addition to the Jewish Museum. I had the smoked trout salad sandwich on rye with pickles and cole slaw. It was fabulous. The homemade rye is superlative. The cole slaw was good and the pickles weren't my favorite kind, but still I enjoyed their presence. The meal was a bit pricey --$13.29, including tax--and I still felt hungry afterward..., but it was quite delish, so if you're trying to decide, I'd say go for it!
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description:
We were downtown and decided to get lunch at the Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen at the Contemporary Jewish Museum. We came in through the gift shop and went through security. I passed my phone/keys/wallet to the guard, and he inspected my partner's bag. She beeped through the gate, but he told her she was fine and so we gathered up our stuff, and made our way through the store, stopping to look at and touch a few items. 

From the store, we made our way into the building lobby and then walked far across that lobby to the restaurant. There was only one party seated, but I could see some people eating outside. We agreed it was too cool and we'd rather sit inside where it was quite nice. We approached the counter and looked at the menu board. I grabbed two menus from the counter and handed one to my partner and we started to talk about what we were going to order. 

The woman working the counter greeted us - "Hi guys, I'm sorry but security asked if you could go back and see them." We were surprised, but we said sure, put the menus back and walked way way back. Did they change their mind about my partner setting off the bell when we came in? Did someone think that we took some merchandise and they were going to search us? Did we possibly leave something of ours at the gate? None of those made sense. 

We cross the lobby, walk through the store, and approach the guard. He's dealing with other people so we stand there - kind of in the way - waiting and waiting. Eventually he looks up and I say "They told us at the deli that you wanted us to come back here." 

"The deli is closed." 

"Yes, well they told us to come over here."

"The deli is open from the outside only. It's closed until 1:00 from the inside." 

It went back and forth like this for a bit; I was mostly very confused. I didn't understand why he was telling us the deli was closed since I was just using that to explain why we were back to speak with him, they said it was his request. He was trying in a very indirect way telling us we weren't allowed to go to the deli - from the inside, until 1.

Eventually it became clear that this was why we were summoned back to security - because we walked without obstruction through a completely open lobby up to a counter at a restaurant that for all anyone could tell was open for business - and we were not permitted to do this. 

But there's no way he could have seen where we went once we left the store - it's a huge building - we could have easily just left through the lobby exit. So it doesn't seem possible that he initiated the call to have us sent back there; what cue would he have? 

And if the deli person didn't want us there because they weren't serving until 1, why didn't they just say "Guys, sorry, we aren't open here until 1. You can get lunch outside though." 

And if the museum doesn't want people walking through a certain part of the building, then why not rope those off? We could see the path to the displays was blocked off. 

We were just trying to be patrons and instead of having a nice lunch, someone called security on us for the act of walking where were clearly permitted to walk. It was extremely unsettling/upsetting; I'm not really interested in being treated this way and can't imagine patronizing either the deli or the museum after that.
author: Steve P.

description:
I had a great experience at the Wise Sons location in the Mission, so I brought my friend over to this location which is closer to where we work. It's located in the Contemporary Jewish Museum, so you actually have to go through a security check to go in and eat. No biggie. The security guard was super friendly and got us through quickly so that we could get to eating. The funny thing is that there are alarmed doors going into the deli too with big signs that say "DO NOT OPEN!", but there must have been two or three people (much older folks) who ignored the signs and set off the alarms during lunch as they were trying to get in and out. LOL!

The food here is just like the other locations which means it's fresh and delicious! I had a turkey sandwich which was tasty and filling. My friend has the pastrami which he totally dug. The space is large and airy and very clean. The staff are super nice and attentive. Extra points for playing New Order's "Power, Corruption, and Lies" while we were there!
author: Jason W.

description:
A tale of two sandwiches.

Mine: Vegan Reuben.  Yum!  Mushrooms had a delicious smoky flavor.  It could have used more kraut and more dressing, but the flavor of everything was superb.  I practically licked my plate.

Husband's: He ordered a corned beef Reuben and they brought a pastrami Reuben.  From his first bite he was disappointed.  It was too smoky.  It upset his stomach.  He actually took it back, though they were very nice about it.  

I suppose given the mix-up and the fact that my husband found the pastrami so smokey it was inedible I should give it less than 4 stars, but when I think of the smoky mushrooms...so good...I can't think of less than 4 stars to describe them.  I'd give the 5 stars if I didn't pay $45 for 3 of us to eat sandwiches, one of which was grilled cheese.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I miss Langer's. I miss Art's. I miss Brent's. I miss Canter's. I miss Los Angeles. I miss the tiny moments I've had with kosher meats in New York. San Francisco does many things well -- like the art of 1-4-24 on power washed streets. But I can count traditional Jewish delis on four toes. So yes, Wise Sons on 24th popped the yamaka off this city. When the Contemporary Jewish Museum open & said, hey, let's have a Jewish deli, with the thunder of a King, they took a Triton, forked it with corned beef and struck into the heart of SF. 

Yes, expensive. I put down a $10 bill and in return earned a thin sheath of salmon between bagels & schmear. But, at least it was Lox, which doesn't exist anywhere downtown. The two words "fish" and "plate" combined are like a refreshing cucumber face mask for my belly. Then when I saw an ode to Langer's with a pastrami on rye, topped with russian dressing and coleslaw, at the very least I can get an edible slice of what I long for. 

Then, they courted De La Paz to be their coffee & operate their cafe. It's a living museum of the things this city needs more of. You keep doing things like this and you'll keep me balanced. I know there are *some* very good pastrami palaces in this city. But when a guy wants a fish plate, Lox, and at the same place within walking distance of the working city, this is it. Walking through the security is like being blessed by the kosher kingdom!
author: Jon A.

description:
Was on mission the other day to get some smoked salmon for brunch. I was actually on my way to a restaurant nearby when I happened to stumble across this spot with a giant sign in front that said "lox and bagel". 

They had seating outside at the park and it was a beautiful day. I decided to give it a try. 

Service was quick. Bagel was great, not what I expected at all. It was thin with not a lot of dough inside. I really liked that since the dough is just unnecessary filling. I would rather have more of the fixings. Could have definitely had a bit more smoked salmon in it, but I chose the closed face one, which they told me would have less inside and was cheaper than the open face bagel. 

Since the sign read "lox" and the menu said "smoked salmon" I had to ask them which it was. They seemed stumped when I asked. They said it's the same thing. Well Wise Sons, actually there is a difference. Here is a link so you can wisen up ;) 

http://www.foodrepublic.com/2013/01/21/whats-difference-between-smoked-salmon-and-lox

What you are serving I believe is smoked salon not technically lox. Regardless I enjoyed it and if I worked nearby would definitely make it a staple lunch. Having been on vacation I will probably not be back. 

P.S. The pickles are good!
author: Lina K.

description:
Going to this location is like boarding an international flight. You are subject to the same level of scrutiny just to be admitted to the cafe. It's at the Jewish museum, so I understand the security... but how about a simple no-fuss entrance just to the deli? 

Perhaps the food just doesn't suit my taste, but I've given it a couple of tries and I have not been wow'ed either time. A lot of my friends love this spot, so perhaps it just a personal preference thing for me. Dont let me dissuade you, try it out for yourself-you may just be in the majority of people that swear by Wise Sons.
author: Vivek N.

description: One of the top 3 pastramis I've had in the Bay Area. Sure, it's not Katz deli.. but it's still solid. Thick, juicy, flavorful! I love this space in the Jewish Museum here... lots of seats, and De La Paz coffee to have after your meal.
author: Kazu O.

description: This location is pretty convenient when you are downtown and want to grab a bite of something delicious. I get a side of the crispy pastrami (only on certain days) and potato salad and that is a good meal for under $10 when they have it. Otherwise it's the pastrami sandwich it's out of this world! The bread is so fresh and duh the pastrami is the way to go here if you don't already know. This location only gets 4 stars because it doesn't have all of the menu choices as the mission location so beware! If you are trying to get an egg sandwich or French fries you are out of luck!
author: Gretchen M.

description: What happened to the Sons?  Got a Pastrami sandwich for $15 -  skimpy portion, half very fatty meat, other half dried up ends.  Pickle slice could not have been smaller.  The bread was good, toss the rest.
author: Joel W.

description:
They advertise & claim to sell bialys. Two BIG problems. 

- That thing called a "bialy" doesn't look or taste like one. Absolute nonsense for a high cost, $3.25. 

- I thought they were baking it from scratch while I waited. It took sooooooo long, at least 10 minutes. No cream cheese, wanted to toast at home. That would take less than a minute in a NY bagel shop. 

Don't bother, seriously.
author: B K.

description: I had the number 19. The pastrami was too salty and the cole slaw was bland and lacked flavor. The black cherry soda brand they sold was mediocre. All in all this deli was a dissapointment.
author: Linda B.

description:
This is NOT food by the ton.  This is deliciously crafted, house made, organic, high quality, subtle, modern deli.  If you want  a huge sandwich with pounds of meat, go to East West Deli on Polk.  

People who have only commented about portion size should go elsewhere, maybe a buffet.  Don't go to the French Laundry, all those little portions, one was just a spoon of someting". LOL

Close your eyes when you chew your pastrami, is it delicious?  Yes.  Extra large, no.  

They also make things to order, you can see the kitchen making everything fresh.  It takes a few minutes.  Order it in advance to go, no waiting.  Plenty of people are willing to wait 10 minutes, have you seen the lines?

The owners are two very nice, caring wise sons, say hello sometime.
author: Tom F.

description:
Wise Sons is a solid option for a San Francisco transplant longing for Cantor's, Nate & Al's and the other deli's he left behind in Los Angeles.  

I got the downtown special - matzo ball soup and half a corned beef sandwich, with coleslaw.  The soup was the highlight - surprisingly good.  I have no doubt my mother exaggerated the difficulty of making a good matzo ball, but that doesn't mean it's easy.  Plenty get it wrong.  Wise got it right.  The corned beef was tasty but for a Jewish deli, it was a very small portion.  Our people have been over-feeding for thousands of years - we know when we're getting shorted.  Cole slaw was to heavy on the mayo.  

I also thought the service was pretty slow and the location in the museum is kind of weird.  I definitely need to try the flagship location.  I'll go back, but more out of convenience and lack of a better option than anything else.
author: Josh P.

description: I'm constantly on a search a great pastrami sandwich that rivals their new york counterparts.  The closest thing I've found so far in CA has been Miller's east coast deli (try it if you haven't already).  I got the pastrami here and it was excellent.  You can tell that they use quality ingredients, and I love that they make their own bread.  I think that Miller's is somewhat juicier but I think I'll have to go to Miller's again to refresh my memory.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Im a little torn about this place. Ive been trying to go to the mission locale for who knows how long now and Im always too late. Ive certainly never had to go through a metal detector for a deli before so this is definitely novel. Got the #9 with pastrami, and a matzoh ball soup. The matzoh had great texture but the soup tasty too healthy. They gotta schmaltz that shit up! I guess they're going for the California lightness to it and I can applaud them for that. I just want the fatty richness. Pastrami was solid, though as some have mentioned, the portions are not awesome for the price. Many old world style places will definitely give you twice the food easily. Still flavors are good and there is just too few delis to complain about this one not being exactly what you're used to.
author: Kim N.

description:
Meh....

i was soo looking forward to getting here after having a mostly positive experience at the mission spot.

only prob i see was that ... their pastrami sandwich was puny!

i took it back and showed the chef and he assured me it was the appropriate size.

only problem is, for a jewish deli, it aint appropriate size  at all.

Katz's, Shermans, Canters ... Their pastrami sandwiches are large!  this comprises a satisfactory pastrami sando at a quality jewish delis.  Not 5 oz. of leaner meat.

wise up wise sons
author: Daniel H.

description: Visited here on the weekend, which was great because it is downtown across from Yerba Buena gardens and was not crowed at lunch time. The pastrami sandwich was so delicious. The meat was very tender and had the perfect amount of saltiness with a light smokey flavor. Their homemade rye bread was also perfect. The best!
author: Rosanne C.

description:
Go all out or go home; that's what I say. It's often difficult to truly enjoy something if you're limiting yourself, after all. So, I finally got to come here this past weekend during brunch and did just that. I ordered a full-on Reuben pastrami sandwich, one of their specialties, with saurkraut and Russian dressing. Crispy bread and Swiss cheese made it perfection. Coleslaw side dish was also quite good.

My other half cannot have beef, but was able to order the smoked trout salad sandwich -- so tasty, it's worth coming here for by itself! Also was able to get a Matzo Ball Soup.

Was nice that Wise Sons provides assigned seating for all guests in the menu "rules" by the time your meal is ready -- it gets crowded in there. It was amusing to sit alongside some admitted "old timers" (as they referred to themselves), who simply could not grasp the concept of us using our smartphones.

My bread did start falling apart mid-sandwich, but for pastrami that good, I'm willing to get my hands messy!
author: Garett T.

description:
Overpriced and not that great, sorry. 
I expected a really good sandwich, especially for $10.50+. See the photo...hardly any brisket in my sandwich. The meat was OK, tender and not dry, but I couldn't help but feel ripped off. Plenty of other better places to eat. Not worth it, even for SF pricing standards.
author: D. H.

description:
I don't get it.  
  
I'm an east coast tribesman, and the food is "ok"  
 
Turkey was a bit dry (everyone at our table for 4 had a bite).  
Corned Beef is traditionally cut thick, this was not.  
Thanks for that micro lemonade!   
A wee bit pricy, but for the area it's expected. 
 
Bread was a plus.  It was not dry. 
Outside seating was nice.  
 
One person in our party was not too happy the food serves did not wear plastic gloves.  Now that does not bother me - but if the guys from Subway can be bothered to...get my drift?  
 
The desserts looked fantastic, but our group was not feeling the place enough to go for it.
author: Adam P.

description:
Yeah.

It's exactly that good.  Yes it's expensive, yes it's a bit of a wait in line at lunchtime, but...it's exactly that good.

You can either eat inside the museum, or, more easily, just wait in line at the window outside for pastrami goodness.  It may take a bit longer than you'd like, and it may set you back a bit more than you'd like, but when you tuck into that delicious morsel of pastrami, kraut, and cheese that is a perfect pastrami reuben, you will forget any small hurdles that were between you and this sandwich, you'll focus only on the relationship of the gooey cheese, the spicy meat, and the crispy toasted bread.  You'll be only briefly distracted by the pickle, before returning to the wonders of the sandwich.  

By the end, your only wish will be that it could be lunchtime all the time
author: Travis B.

description:
Good but basic.
Went to one star because:
- ridiculously slow even when not busy.
- Overcharging tax.  The register rings up with extra tax.  They are going to have an issue when I report this on Monday. 
- charge for a paper bag even when you don't want one.
- register girl who couldn't care less.
author: Ric S.

description: Jewish deli, but no Passover menu. Pretty disappointed. SF is lacking in Jewish cuisine.
author: Tara M.

description: If you're looking for a tasty, freshly made sandwich downtown then this is the place for you. I particularly like the pastrami sandwich as it's tastier than the corned beef. The side of potato salad was delicious & I'm not a lover of potato salad. A touch pricy though at $15 incl tax & cheese....ps they're open on weekends despite the info on their website.
author: Nicole E.

description:
Let's start with the fact that this place is connected to the Contemporary JEWISH Museum and it is called Wise Sons JEWISH Delicatessen and yet come time for a JEWISH holiday, Passover, do they have anything Kosher for Passover? No.  No specials for Passover and when I went to order just the Matzah Ball Soup and asked if it was Kosher for Passover, the employee's exact words were, "Nothing here is Kosher for Passover".  SERIOUSLY?!  I walked halfway across town, because lets be honest there are NO Jewish deli's in SF, on my lunch hour and you are telling me I can't get anything to eat here at all when it is ATTACHED TO THE JEWISH MUSEUM?! I mean come on.  Big Fail Wise Sons.  Big Fail. 

Thanks to Shorty Goldstein's for at least having a small Kosher for Passover menu.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Knowing this is a sandwich shop I hungrily ordered a cobb salad.  Thinking their top teir meats would put a bit of a spin on the traditional dish. BIG MISTAKE. Almost $13 later, Im still hungry. 

Meats are a garnish at best. Not even a whole egg!

The ingredients were fresh but I feel ripped off even for San Francsico. 

Why even have a Cobb Salad if its not made to actually fill someone up? Especially at those prices.
author: K O.

description:
Had the Pastrami Reuben. The bread is crisp with just the right amount of butter, so that it looks golden when toasted. The pastrami is juicy and full of good flavor and spices, comparable to the best pastrami's I had in New York.

Only reason it is not 5 stars is the price. $18 lunch is a little bit out of range for me to go on a regular basis.
author: Takahisa H.

description:
Ok, maybe it was me who made the mistake of ordering a salad at a Jewish deli, but still... what I got, for the price of 12 bucks, was the smallest cobb salad ever. It was more like a side salad. I wolfed it down and was still starving. To be fair, my two lunch mates ordered off the sandwich menu and their servings weren't much bigger. This place gives Jewish delis a bad name. 
Was it at least tasty? Meh....
author: Cowbella H.

description: Some of the worst service ever.  The "waiter" talked down to us and asked us if we knew what the word "autonomous" meant.  Seating situation was horrible.  Avoid at all costs.
author: Ian C.

description:
Great new delicatessen that features tasty sandwiches and traditional Jewish fare. Lately, I've been training to run a marathon (ehh....let's not go into that) and so I was starving when I got here. I probably should have gotten some lite salad. Did I? F#@) No. I probably should have gotten just water to drink. Did I? F#)% No. Instead I got this thing called Pastrami Cheese Fries and a Corned Beef sandwich with a fried egg. Oh and I ordered an Anchor Steam to go along with it. Ok, wow that felt good to get it off my chest. 

Needless to say, everything was tasty and done very well. The place was very clean, a great space, and the cashier was nice enough to answer any questions I had and was helpful in offering recommendations. My only gripe about this place was that it was fairly expensive for a deli, 14.50 for a simple sandwich?!?! Definitely cannot afford to eat here everyday or else I'll have to scavenge for cans from the dumpster out back. Nevertheless, for all you people with trust funds and pretend like you don't (you know who you are), this would be a great place to enjoy a lunch at.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The Dish: After hearing many great things about this place, I came here with my coworker. I kind of expected something amazing, but I've definitely tasted better & more flavorful pastrami. Nevertheless, the pastrami on rye was okay. I think the rye was definitely fantastic, but there wasn't much more flavor than just that. My coworker got the Matzoh Ball Soup, which was absolutely delicious. How she describes it is "just really, really good chicken noodle soup." If I visited again, I'd order the soup and the potato salad.

Ambiance: The line starts early! We got there around 11:30 and the line was pretty line. Service was kind of slow - took awhile (15-20 minutes to get us our order).
author: Gina T.

description: Best bagels I've had in SF! I'm addicted to the everything bagel with lox. They get swamped at lunch, so be prepared to wait!
author: E G.

description:
Stopped here for lunch today during a break from training.  I had the pastrami reuben sandwich (no sauerkraut).  It was absolutely amazing.   The meat was super tender, juicy and plenty to eat!  The bread wss nicely grilled with a delicious crunch.  I also got a side of potato salad with it and that was great as well.  
Enjoyed my meal on a bench In the sun which was very relaxing.
Although it was a little expensive, 6 hours later, I'm still full!  
I think I'll go back tomorrow to try the corned beef :)  Highly recommend this place!
author: M E.

description: If I had a bubbe that made matzo ball soup she would be rolling in her grave over Wise Sons' version. Just downright bland. The pastrami reuben (with a shriveled up pickle on the side) and my bialy with smoked salmon wasn't too exciting as well. The chocolate babka was probably the only thing worth repeating, but for $40 for lunch for 2, I would search elsewhere for better eats. I love the fact that its in the Jewish Contemporary Museum (worth a visit in its own right) and there's a lovely outdoor patio to enjoy said eats, but oy vey- what a disappointment!
author: Ritu K.

description:
The corned beef reuben was delicious as were side dishes of coleslaw and potato salad.
My only comment was the quantity of meat - could have been more generous - one of two more slices would have made the meal perfect!
I guess I'm an east coast deli maven at heart and used to overly generous portions.
Not the case in most Calfornia establishments.
author: nadeen b.

description: Wonderful pastrami and corned beef! I've never had better, and I've had nothing as good in San Francisco.
author: Mohammed A.

description: Very good Matzo Ball Soup--may even be museum quality as listed.  Fun place to take a break when visiting the excellent museum
author: AV G.

description:
Brian and Kai were both really helpful and sweet. Excellent employees- lucky Wise Sons!

While we were enjoying the museum, they got our order together so that it was ready right before they closed. So, we were able to then sit outside and enjoy absolutely yummmmmy sandwiches and chocolate babka to (almost) die for. Both the chopped liver and the turkey were terrific. The rye bread was so good, we had to buy a loaf to share and take home.

Even the lemonade was good,-not too sweet or watered down.

My second time there, and I'd go back in a New York minute!
author: Deb M.

description: Service was fast, bathrooms clean, menu is pretty basic. Each of us had a combo reuben, potato salad and cole slaw. the sandwich was awesome and its the second time I've had the good potato salad, cole slaw was ok. It cost $47 total!! Wow... Not sure I need to go there again.
author: Michelle L.

description:
i want to like this place at the museum on Mission St., but they have a sign at the take out window: "Bagels and Lox".
I asked for a bagel: "we don't have bagels."
"Do you ever have bagels?"
"Never at this location."
SF has NO GOOD BAGELS! what kind of city is this!
When they are at the Ferry Bldg one day a week they have good bagels and they are very nice there.
Please take down your "Bagels" sign at the museum. It is not nice to tease.
Thank you.
author: becke a.

description:
Restaurant, n.: a place that seats people, takes orders, and serves food.

Wise Sons, museum edition, n.: a place that discontinues service in the middle of lunch rush on a Saturday, despite the presence of OPEN tables, because they are too overwhelmed by orders.

This place is not new.  Lunch is not a new concept.  Discontinue the TAKEOUT orders if you must, but seat and serve the people who arrived to eat at your "restaurant."

(And hire enough competent people to handle lunch for a couple dozen folks.)

EDIT: one star for today.  Two more for the joy bialys and smoked fish from the kiosk brought me during the months I worked nearby.
author: Ken W.

description:
I will start by saying that the food overall was very good. My #19 sandwich (with pastrami) was tasty and the smoked trout sandwich that my fiancee had was also very good. I would suggest slicing the meat thinner as it's harder to take bites when it's as thick as it was. The celery soda was unique because it was freshly prepared, however, after sitting in my cup with ice for so long (see the next part of my review), it simply became too watered down.

Now for my gripe. I was told by a museum staff member that today, Christmas Day, is the busiest day of the year for the museum and subsequently Wise Sons. Unfortunately, they didn't staff accordingly so we ended up waiting an hour to order and another 40 minutes to get our food. It seems like they pared down their regular menu for today as there were a number of items on their website that were not available for purchase. That makes sense given the large number of customers being served, however, it wasn't enough. To make matters worse, the cashier didn't seem fazed by how long we waited in line and failed to tell us how long the wait would be for the food. After half an hour I asked how long it would be. The woman I spoke to said she would check. She came back to me and handed me two mandelbread cookies and said ten minutes. Again, unfazed and unapologetic. 

I realize that on Christmas Day you're the only game in town and people are often willing to put up with a lot, but an hour and 40 minutes for 4 sandwiches and a couple of drinks was just too much. Perhaps Wise Sons should have considered adding more staff or closing the 'to go' window and focus on the customers inside the restaurant, or have everyone (including management) helping to get orders taken and prepared. Anything would have helped!
author: Mark G.

description: Good sandwich, less good service, really expensive. took a reaaaally long time to get my sando. however, they comped me a cookie to make up for it, which was nice. but $20 for a sandwich and an iced tea? come on now, son.
author: Erica W.

description:
While visiting the Jewish Museum, we thought a dinning experience at a Jewish deli appropriate.  We ordered a Rueben with pastrami,  a matzo ball soup & a side of cole- slaw.  

What we got was amazingly bad.  The Rueben was a half-inch slab of tough, dried out pastrami between two slices of naked rye bread.  The soup was watery & bland with a giant matzo ball in the middle tasting like and with the  consistency of a small, white bowling ball!  The cole-slaw was tasty though it looked like it had been sitting around for a few weeks.

Although we live in the Mission, the above experience precludes our visiting their 24th Street venue.
author: Robert K.

description:
I'm so happy that I can get my pastrami fix downtown now and 7 days a week! Considering my short lunch hour I was a bit worried that I would be cutting it close, but I was able to order and get my food in a snap without the quality of the food compromised. And there was plenty of time to enjoy my matzo ball soup in one of my favorite plazas downtown.

They are not your NY deli that everyone loves to compare them to. They are better. Their house-made meats are drool worthy and double baked rye the best. Did your fond memories of that NY deli really make all their own meats and bread? Probably not. Break from your preconceived "memories" of the NY deli and just taste the food and enjoy!

Glad to see De La Paz in the Fidi/SoMa mix. Nothing beats Jose's almost milk lattes.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great somewhat smaller version of the Mission Deli with the same great quality.  It was awesome to see Leo (co-founder) at this store helping to prepare and serve the food - thanks!  I will continue to be coming in for lunch - great!  

PS - awesome coleslaw!  i'm picky so this is hard to find...
author: Michael S.

description:
This is a combo review for both the Mission and Museum locations. 

I'd had the matzoh brei at the original location, and had been pretty disappointed by the rubberiness of it....I've been making the dish since I was a kid, and mine is far better (just being honest). I mentioned my disappointment to the cashier, but she didn't really have any solution. 

Today I visited the new location, and got the vegetarian (mushroom) reuben. It was better than the matzoh brei, but there seemed to be an odd metallic flavor I couldn't quite place. Definitely not the kind of thing I'd want to eat again. 

Also, it'd be nice if they had more seating options for solo lunch diners.
author: David Z.

description: Damn good sandwiches! Been here a couple of times now, got the reuben pastrami the first time and I don't think I'll ever look back. They give you a fair bit of pastrami with the sandwiches, and the more meat the merrier. The sandwiches are a bit on the pricier side, but they are hella' delicious. If you are feeling the need for a pastrami sandwich, look no further than wise sons!
author: David C.

description:
Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen... A Jewish deli inside a Jewish museum? Must be good! Seems like you can go inside the museum to eat versus the hole in the wall window to order. Most likely the window is for to go orders and inside is for sit down.

== Food ==

Pastrami on rye. Quite delicious. The pastrami literally melted in my mouth. It's so soft! The slice of rye was really soft and fresh.

== Service ==

Grabbed the sandwich to go and beat the lunch rush and was able to order before a line formed. The sandwich took 5-10 minutes to be prepared. Kinda of slow considering it's such a simple sandwich to make. What's the hold up?

== Overall ==

Delicious pastrami. Definitely a regular lunch spot for me.
author: Steven B.

description: Nightmare wait times at the take out window. Steer clear unless you have endless patience.
author: Sam S.

description: Matzo ball soup is very delicious. Good portion for the price. Setting is not awesome insane but outside it's quite pleasant with a nice view.
author: Anne M.

description: We're baffled by the bad reviews of this place. About the price: this is located in a museum, so you have to expect museum cafe prices for the entree. We're locals and we found our portions just right. The rye bread was the best we've had since our local deli stopped carrying L.A. rye. The Reuben sandwich was very good, the potato salad was great (couldn't figure out what they put in it to give it that flavor), and the lox and bagel with cream cheese was also excellent. We're happy we tried it!
author: Berk H.

description: Great pastrami and bread but light on the portion. Served with just bread and meat and to go mayo and mustard w a side of cole slaw. Very nice service.
author: Linda N.

description: I'm addicted to the smoked trumpet mushrooms. The smoked trout salad's amazing. The babka. I'm a chocoholic, but in this case I think the cinnamon babka's even better. The matzo balls. The bread. The chopped liver. The special events are always engaging and delicious.
author: Olga Z.

description: I'm all for appropriate price for quality, but this place is disappointing. Charging just because you can is for crappy restaurants in tourist locations. $16 after tax for a turkey Reuben. It's good, but not 60% better than a $10 Reuben good.
author: Evan R.

description: I've had many Rubens from the 24th street store. The pastrami there is wonderful.  Just had a Ruben here.  Took 2 bites and tossed it. Pastrami was like leather.  Waste of $14 on a crappy sandwich.
author: Steve P.

description: Had the downtown special, very nice Matza Ball with my chicken soup, had excellent potato salad and decent egg salad on rye. Just right for a guy missing the east coast. I'll be back for lunch again!
author: Evanharris H.

description:
I want to like this place. Their pastrami is fully 8 of 10. But the take-out window has some serious issues:

1. Buy a goddamn awning. At lunch, the sun is focussed on this place like a laser. You will easily spend 20 minutes waiting to order. Be advised and bring some SPF. Or maybe Wise Sons can do everybody a solid and provide some shade.

2. The 40 minute wait (inclusive of the first 20) for your order. Come on. Their classic pastrami has two ingredients. Bread + pastrami! Slice it, put it in the box, and let's go already!

3. It's $15 for a sandwich--a sandwich with TWO ingredients.
author: robert h.

description:
I love Pastrami.  I've made the pilgrimage to Katz in NYC.  So I had to order the Pastrami Reuben at Wise Sons.  The outdoor line at noon wasn't too terrible and the weather cooperated fairly well. 

The sandwich was crispy and warm with no tough parts.  The pastrami was moist with a good salty crust.  The pickles on the side were a nice complement as well.  So in terms of the sandwich's taste, it was definitely top tier.  The problem was with the value.  The sandwich cost $12 but was remarkably thin, seemingly only a few slices worth of meat in the middle (thick-ish slices, but certainly not Katz thick).  Another person in my group ordered the same and his looked thicker.  For the price, I want a reliably robust sandwich - ideally a Katzian pile of meat, or at least something it takes me longer than 30 seconds to finish.  Otherwise... yum!
author: Martin H.

description: Move over you smug NY delis! Wise Sons is the real deal plus a a generous helping of California creativity! Just try their vegetarian Reuben with smoked mushrooms! And what could possibly top noshing on the deck overlooking the Yerba Buena vista!  This is the place to go after visiting MOMA - or whenever one needs a fix of deli done right!
author: Paul S.

description: Wise Sons is an amazing restaurant.  Their pastrami is some of the best you'll have and they also have a great egg cream soda.  This location has an easy take out window located outside the Jewish Museum which makes it simpler and quicker to grab your food on the go.
author: Matthew L.

description: Dropped in here after visiting the museum yesterday.  Both my father and I had the the Downtown Special, with matzo ball soup and a half sandwich.  I had the chopped liver, my father had the pastrami.  The matzo ball soup was plentiful, maybe not as seasoned as I like, but that's often the issue with matzo ball soup.  Enjoyed the chopped liver sandwich, although again, maybe a bit more seasoning.  In general, good, comfort food, and large portions.  One minor issue, you are expected to bus your own table, which a lot of people don't.  So you may have to bus a table sit down.
author: Gail D.

description: I went here because of a 7x7 article saying it had the best sandwiches in San Francisco. I had a decent pastrami sandwich. Wouldn't say it was the best. Nice place for a bite during a lunch break.
author: T J.

description:
Craving a corned beef sandwich and some matzo ball soup I tried this place. Bringing with me a bunch of friends as we were all in a class together. 

I would have to say that the sandwich was a little fatty and skimpy on the meat. The rye bread had such a hard crust that you can cut your gums. 

As for the soup. It was ok. Not moms or even stuff can make with a mix.  

May be back to try again..
author: Rob S.

description: Haven't tried their food but their challah is the best I've found in SF. Better than Irv's Premium.
author: Mark F.

description: I agree that their prices are a bit high but it is worth it, specially if you a reuben sandwich fan.  They have the best reuben (corn beef pastrami) in the area, and the space at the Jewish Museum is beautiful.
author: Terry K.

description: I should declare up front that this is a pretty expensive deli; not Katz's (Manhattan) expensive, but not quite the same quality, either. That said, I have few complaints about my food. My pastrami had nice flavor, rich with beef and smoke, not too briny. The texture was a little tough, not the fall-apart tenderness that I like, but still good. My side cole slaw was tasty, but not too remarkable. They have a nice drink selection and the people working here are pretty nice. I'll give them a (hedged) four star rating. Note: if you order from the takeout window, security is no issue.
author: Joel R.

description: I would give this place 5 starts if the price was a bit more reasonable...we went here for lunch with some coworkers and it was great, but we ended up paying $18 for a sandwich and a water. It seemed a bit much although the food itself was delicious.
author: George M.

description: I love the food here, but the wait time for a bialy and matzoh ball soup from their take out window should not be 20 minutes. I keep coming back though.
author: S. S.

description: This is my favorite place for lunch.  Love the open faced salmon sandwich.  Also really like the matzah ball soup and pastrami sandwiches.  Would be nice not to be metal detected going there but safety from raging antisemites is a small price for a fine corned beef sandwich.
author: Jeff B.

description: I left after 10 minutes waiting for an iced coffee when it wasn't even busy. Place ice in cup. Pour coffee in. Way to go guys :)
author: Alex G.

description:
We dined at the restaurant on a Saturday afternoon for lunch.  

The restaurant is set up in an awkward configuration in what used to be part of the main lobby of the museum.  

- Most of the seating is inside, with a few tables outside.  However, the doors between the inside and outside eating areas are locked, so one has to go out the main museum doors and past the security metal detector to sit outside.
- The dining room was far too small for the crowds there.  People were waiting in the wings for tables while other patrons were grabbing tables while their friends were inline.  A staff member directing the tables would have gone a long way.  For a bit we ended up at a table for four and only 2 chairs.


Food:
I tried to order the lunch combo, which is a classic sandwich, side, and drink for $13.75.  Even though the menu made no mention of this, the only sides allowed are cole slaw or potato salad.  There are several other sides on the menu, such pickles and green salad that I was informed are not part of the combo.  I'm fine with that - just put it on the menu - don't surprise me when I'm ordering.

Overall, the portions were very small for the price charged.  I did not feel that the place had good value at all.  The brisket was quite dry and had not been well trimmed of fat.  Overall, I left $10.50 poorer and still quite hungry.

Although I did not see it first hand, a female member of our group reported the bathrooms to be filthy and that she had to "squat around" the toilet, whatever that means.

Too bad too - because I love a good Jewish Deli and work a block away.  Sigh - I guess it's back to Miller's.
author: Steve B.

description:
Was underwhelmed by my hot pastrami. $15 and change for a sando plus side and drink was standard for a NYC style deli sando (they charged $0.50 for lettuce). 

Meat was tasty but problem is they serve half the amount of meat you would get at a proper NYC style deli. Don't mind paying a premium for a real hot pastrami just not one that leaves me hungry. 

Miller's East Coast on Polk St. remains the best NYC style deli I've found in SF.
author: Gere G.

description:
If you've heard the hype and decided to give the new location a try, you're better off not.

Maybe that's what I get for being an early adopter.

Monday, after a Friday opening.  Surprisingly short line to order.  Being a proper deli junkie I'm thrilled.  

Although I'm suspect since there seem to be a lot of people waiting for their order.  I order.  I pay, I look in the window and see 30 lunch tickets waiting to be prepared.  "Amy" comes to the counter and complains, says she's been waiting 30 minutes and if her order doesn't come out in a minute that she wants her money back.  

I panic.  I cancel my order.  

I can't resist, I love a good pastrami, and i'm heard nothing but amazing things.  I give in and change my mind.  

I wait about 12 minutes, it's OK.  I appreciate you're busy.

I think about pastrami for the next 10 minutes on my walk back to the office.

Sadly, not a work of Art fit for a restaurant located in a museum.  A few piece of incredibly fatty pastrami unlovingly put on some bread.  Such little meat between the slices of bread that the sandwich actually falls apart.  You know you've been there. 

A huge disappointment for sure.  Mediocre amounts of fatty, unflavored pastrami in a sandwich that falls apart.
author: Che D.

description:
Absolutely the worst Jewish deli food ever served!

Pastrami was 80% fat; meat was so tough it could resole my shoes.

Matzahball soup was bland without a hint of chicken meat or flavor.

Expensive... Save your money!

Wise Sons wisdom does not include running a deli.

I had to give one star in order to post this WARNING. It does not rate even one star.
author: Lynn S.

description: A terrible/sad thing happened to us today at Wise Sons in the Contemporary Jewish Museum -they REFUSED to serve us matzah when we tried to order lunch.  It is the Jewish holiday of Passover, how could they refuse?  When I called the main deli they could not have cared less and referred me to the museum...from where I was calling.   I understand they are a commercial establishment and don't quibble with the fact they serve bread but to not serve matzah on Passover?  Shame Shame  on them and never again will we eat at any of their venues!
author: Robin M.

description: I really want to like this place, but the order taking process needs work. A lot. I just ordered a turkey sandwich and was not informed that it would be just meat and bread. For $10. No mustard or mayo even. I understand that you charge extra for lettuce, tomato, onion or capers since most people probably order the hot pastrami, corned beef or some of the menu sandwiches, but this left me legitmately disappointed. However, the turkey did taste great it was just plain and dry without any accompaniments.
author: Jared C.

description:
Way overpriced. There's a reason the Sentinel has a line out the door, while this place has bupkis. $10.50 for barely any meat on rye? Give me a break.

Head to the Deli Board in Soma, or Moishe's Pipic in Hayes Valley if you want a good corned beef/pastrami sandwich. (Moishe's is similarly priced, but with like 3 times the meat.)
author: Sean H.

description: Great Sunday trip and just easy. Hot soup delicious , ohhh great space with lots of room and not too loud. Great hidden place to just relax. The food is okay.
author: P C.

description: I have friends raving about this place so i wanted to give it a shot but it's just OK - i ordered roast beef sandwich, it has sourkraut kind of thing inside but  i don't think those two goes well with each other, i would rather go with plain aioli and make it taste better.
author: Beril Y.

description: Hands down the best Lox/Bagel I've ever had. Worth the wait.
author: Brian V.

description: The trout salad sandwich is excellent, especially on a bialy. Had the potato salad on the side.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This is a "Meh" review, though I wasn't willing to give only 2 stars to invoke that rating officially.  I came because I was hungry, cold, and had just heard the night before that I had to go here for the Matzo Ball soup. 

I ordered at the takeout window by a lady who wasn't friendly, but I wouldn't say she was actually rude.  We'll leave it at "brusque".  I was an easy customer:  my only question was if they could accept credit cards (they can).  I knew what I wanted and the transaction was quick.  I then waited nearby, with other foodless people who had ordered before I got there.

I ordered the fabled Matzo Ball soup and a bottled water. A bit pricey, but I was there to experience this soup.  I received the water and sat down at one of the nice outside tables, and waited.  And waited.  For awhile nobody received anything from that window, but after about 5 minutes somebody received food, and this slowly progressed until about 12-15 minutes later when my soup arrived. That's along time for soup that is generally sitting in a pot waiting to be plopped into a bowl. It was hot, and well packaged in a serviceable lidded container, in a plastic bag, and then in a paper bag with a spoon and napkin. The guy that called out that my order was ready was very pleasant.

I will confess that I do make my own Matzo Ball soup from scratch (okay, I buy the matzo meal, but smashing my own matza doesn't really enhance the finished product).  I acknowledge that a home cook's signature soup is usually going to be deemed better than a restaurant version, particularly when we're dealing with something as loaded with tradition and memories as soup,  All that said:  the soup was a bit bland.  Mind you, it was much better than the weirdly austere versions I've had at a few Seders where the broth has been skimmed and strained down to an anemic plasma suitable for injection.  There was actual chicken skin and fat in this.  There were large bits of chicken, a few carrots, some skinny noodles (?), and a big fluffy matzo ball. Carrots I like.  Why not some onion, celery, maybe a hint of garlic or an herb for flavor?  You can do a lot without adding more salt. There's no playing the purist card, because you've got noodles in there.  I could do without those, but they're not hurting anything and they do add a little food value.  The matzo ball itself had a nice texture, able to keep it's shape without danger of destroying the plastic spoon. There wasn't much flavor in the thing though. I'm not sure the ball spent a lot of time in the broth, or perhaps the broth failed to impart much flavor.  I always cook my matzo balls in the broth for maximum flavor, but perhaps they do theirs separately for the sake of handling to volume of orders. 

I won't be back for the soup.  It is healthy and fairly hearty, but not worth the wait or the price.
author: Julian F.

description:
The same amazing grub as their Mission spot, in the very chic Contemporary Jewish Museum. Love the outdoor seating - the view of the plaza is a pretty incredible way to scarf down a pastrami sandwich. 

Oh, and they have a full espresso bar!
author: Zac B.

description:
Overpriced and really not that great.

My 12 dollar sandwich consisted of the small pieces of the rye bread right before the end piece, and a paltry piece of meat. Even the pickle slices were small.

It was more of a snack than a lunch. Never going again.
author: Amy T.

description:
I love their little window for ease of ordering on a nice day, and the staff was very friendly.
I got the turkey sandwich, which I'm sure most people would love, and I did love most parts of it.  The smoked turkey was nice, the bread was phenomenal, the pickled onions were the bomb, and the arugula was a really nice touch.  It's all ruined for me when the honey mustard is really honey "spicy/whole" mustard.  I have this hatred of all things horseradish you see (though I love the greens in that family, go figure) - horseradish, wasabi, whole mustard seeds, "spicy" mustard (unless it's Sriracha based) - any of that nasal passage clearing nonsense, it's just not my jam.
But, if you like that flavor, you will probably think this sandwich (and it's accompanying potato salad) was amazing and you're probably right.  As for me, I guess I'm just not a Jewish Delicatessen sort of girl.  
Four stars since next time I will just get it without the mustard and it'll probably be the best turkey sandwich I've had in a while.
author: Jennifer D.

description: Cozy place to hangout. Food is amazing. Had the corned beef #19, oh man, messy and delicious. So excited they're here!!
author: Weyland L.

description:
When visiting San Francisco this past week we stopped in to eat at Wise Sons newest location in the Jewish Contemporary Museum. We had eaten at the 24th Street location the month before and were extremely pleased with our wonderful feast of pastrami reuben, matzoh ball soup and of course their amazing chocolate babka. 
Their new digs did not disappoint. What a beautiful venue. We ordered the house-made corned beef, pastrami and turkey on delicious Wise Sons rye bread. We couldn't leave without taking a piece of babka for the road. We hope that Wise Sons will open in the Los Angeles area one day soon.
author: L J.

description: Been here many times, will keep going back - always delicious food and the location in YB is perfect for a quick bite outdoors. Keep it up!
author: Alex B.

description:
Excellent ingredients. We ate outside. Bread for sandwiches were fresh. Pastrami was lean. Turkey not dry. Would definitely eat here again.

I am editing this because I just got my credit card statement and they somehow added to my bill. My receipt has one $ amount and my bill has another. I am guessing this is not a American Express issue. Annoyed. 

So if you eat here. Bring cash. We were on a business trip so receipts were essential. Glad I have it.
author: myra f.

description: decently priced food for the area. reuben with mozza ball soup. not anything spectacular.
author: David L.

description: Went to Wise Sons for a team lunch today and really enjoyed it! The decor is awesome - high ceilings, exposed brick, open kitchen, modern furniture... and your typical old school deli menu board with the black and red plastic letters and numbers. Ordered the Top Seed Turkey Sandwich which was fantastic - just the right proportions of every ingredient. It was a little expensive for the overall portion size otherWise I'd give it four stars (of David).
author: Gina C.

description: I got the Smoked Mushroom Reuben. Portions are kind of small, but so delicious!
author: Lilian K.

description: The food here is delicious. I got a matza ball soup and pastrami sandwich and it was soooo good. Can't wait to go back!
author: Rachel C.

description: I enjoyed my lunch with the rest of the Congregation Sherith Israel group who attended the museum November 1. The lunches were pre-made and fortunately, the bread wasn't too soggy on my egg salad sandwich. The portion was generous but I found it easier to eat it open face with a fork rather than wear it on my shirt. If there were a few more choices for vegetarian items, that would be terrific (hint, hint) like a hummus with pita bread plate accompanied by cole slaw and potato salad, for example.
author: Adrienne K.

description:
Great pastrami reuben!  I cant wait to try some of the other options.
The only reason I didn't give it a 5, is that it's a slower line and a couple more dollars than the Sentinel which is a couple blocks away.
I'll be going back to this place a lot.
author: Jeffrey H.

description: Good solid 3. Great potato salad. Nice pastrami with very fresh bread. Counter help were friendly and did not mind multiple refills of tea.
author: ben h.

description: What a pleasant find.  My husband & I had lunch here last week.  We both ordered the matzo ball soup & half pastrami sandwich.  We tried the coleslaw & the potato salad.  You order at the front counter & they bring your food to you.  We enjoyed it all and they really loaded the meat on the sandwich.  My husband thought the soup was a bit bland but I thought it had great flavor.  We enjoyed sitting by the window & looking at the cool world globe sculpture above.  We'll be back here!
author: Donna W.

description: I would give it a ZERO if that were possible. Absolutely the WORST corned beef sandwich I have ever eaten and I have eaten a lot of corned beef sandwiches. About 3 pieces of so called corned beef on really small bread. The beef was about 80% fat and I did ask for "lean" corned beef. HORRIBLE and overpriced. Don't go there EVER!!!
author: Hilary B.

description: Just want to quickly update that I had another great meal here. I suggest the combo with 1/2 pastrami sandwich, matzoh ball soup and potato salad!!
author: Laurence S.

description:
The Museum space is beautiful and Wisesons has made this feel more
like a restaurant  with its own separate experience. The salmon bialy with
capers was fantastic and pastrami fabulous, light soft rye with dense meat
and pickles amazing. Care and consideration put into everything they do.
So glad Wisesons is gaining an even wider exposure in the downtown.
Best wishes guys.
author: Carla Q.

description:
This rating is based more on service than food. 
I enjoyed my meal. I had the veggie Reuben with potato salad and a black cherry cane soda. The potato salad could have used a little more seasoning and my mushrooms were chewier than I expect but overall it was a pleasant experience.
My biggest issue was when I was leaving. I wanted to get a box to go but no one seemed interested in helping me. The waitress was waiting for the food handler to fill orders and put them into paper bags and the girl at the register was waiting for someone to order. I stood in front of the boxes saying excuse me about 5 times until the kitchen staff finally helped me and gave me a box. I don't really think that on top of making the food they should have to also attend to customers. 
To be quite frank, I felt some racial tension between the kitchen staff and the front counter. I probably won't return until there is more diversity in their staff. I understand this is a Jewish deli but that didn't stop them from hiring a Latino kitchen staff. I would like to see more people of color having equal positions in this establishment. Maybe then I'll be able to get a to go box without having to ask repeatedly.
author: Liz P.

description: First visit today, a bit disappointing.  When I think Jewish Deli, I think of great (grand) sandwiches piled high.... this was nothing like that.  It had the price of a grand sandwich, but the meat-stack of a hospital cafeteria.  Much too small for a $17 lunch combo.  Taste was fine, not stellar, on my Reuben, but the coleslaw was actually very tasty.  They either need to reduce the price or make a proper sando.   This was a strong disappointment after walking 8 blocks just to try it.  If the price-to-food ratio was better I would rate this a 3.5, but I'm still searching for a great Jewish Deli that can compare with something from Manhattan, and this isn't the place.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Sadder than a very sad thing

I met up with a friend for lunch at Wise Sons on our way to see the Arnold Lobel show. The space is gorgeous--warm brick wall, tons of natural light. The only thing I didn't understand aesthetically were the nails pounded into the surface of the tables. What image are they supposed to conjur? They would wreck anyone wearing a delicate fabric and looked painful, but would definitely keep pens from rolling off the table.

I arrived at 12:45 and she had ordered for us after twenty minutes in line. Thirty minutes later our food arrived. I don't understand the American thing about not enough people behind the counter. I understand it was during their lunch rush, but a good business hires enough people to keep the line and and the food moving. My friend ordered the vegan reuben, which looked like a traditional cafeteria-style reuben (albeit short--nothing like Katz's) and came with a heap of potato salad. The faux meat tasted of liquid smoke and the potato salad was more salad than potato. But that wasn't the worst of it: I ordered the chinese chicken salad ($9.50) and what arrived was a heap of paper-dry slaw with three crispy things on top and a slice of rye bread. Huh? Where's the chicken? I dug down to the bottom of the bowl and there were three grey, sad pieces of chicken that looked like fingernails. At this point, I was starving, but reluctantly brought it to our server's attention. I asked for something else: a turkey sandwich. 

At this point, the rush had dwindled, so as I waited for the sandwich, I went up to the counter to order espresso drinks. The person at the register told me the espresso machine was broken. (I could see it, sitting there, at the end of the prep line--no note taped to it.) Huh? A cafe with a huge sign advertising espresso?!! I got the impression that they weren't telling me the truth. At this point, with a pounding headache, I ordered two house coffees, which were served to me in paper cups and were $2.50 each. So disappointing. (There is apparently a window that serves to the outside--not sure which orders take priority when both the inside restaurant and the walkup window are ordering.)

The turkey sandwich arrived in ten minutes (whoa, that was fast!). It was so sad! The sliced turkey had that chemical preservative taste and was pressed next to a very pale piece of lettuce on that same sad light rye bread. I've had better meals in a hospital. The best thing about the sandwich was the dab of mustard. It came with pickle spears (one was crisp, the other two soggy) and guess what? Cole slaw. The same slaw as the chicken salad but with sauce. I was starving but the sandwich was really unpleasant. To the deli's credit, they brought us a free bowl of matso ball soup and apologized, which was a nice gesture. The soup, however, was luke warm, which defeats the purpose of soup, and at the bottom of the bowl were more sad, dry grey shards of chicken. Ew! I ended up eating the carrots out of the soup and a few bites of the sandwich. Left disappointed and hungry. The most discomforting "comfort food" I've ever had.

By the time we left the place, the inside had emptied out and it looked like they closed early. It's a bus-your-own-table joint, but we saw several patrons leave who didn't get the message. I don't mind bussing my own table--the compost bin got a lot of food off my plates.

The worst part about this restaurant is that with its location and cuisine, it could and should be absolutely fabulous. It should be the gem of the neighborhood.

My idea of a delicious salad is served only a block (443 feet) away at The Grove Yerba Buena (690 Mission Street). Their chinese chicken salad is $10.75 ($1.25 more than Wise Sons). When you order a salad there that claims to have chicken in it, you see the chicken proudly piled on top, in a generous amount. The quality of their ingredients is far superior and at a comparable price point. Yes, they get busy, too, but their ordering line moves smoothly and they bring the food out in a much more timely fashion.

I'm not sure what's so wise about Wise Sons. Won't be back.
